div1.p: As it is Acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL in DRURY-LANE.
div1.l: In amore haec omnia insunt vitia; injuriae,
div1.p: LONDON: Printed for P. VAILLANT, facing Southampton-Street in the Strand. MDCCLXI.

div1.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div1.p: THE first hint of this Comedy was suggested by the Cocu Imaginaire of Moliere, who took the idea of his piece from an Italian writer. Though jealousy, in all its appearances, has been frequently exhibited on the English stage, yet it was imagined that a plan, which should delineate all the varieties of that passion, whether subsisting between lovers or in the matrimonial life, and blend them together in one piece, would not be unacceptable to the public. If therefore there is atonement made for the want of originality of character by the decency of the dialogue, the novelty of the fable, and the complication of the incidents, the author has compassed all that he proposed to himself in the ensuing scenes; which, with pleasure he finds, were the occasion of producing the too long concealed powers of Miss Haughton, and of shewing, in a distinguished light, the exquisite acting of Mr. Obrien.

div3.head: SCENE the Park.
div3.stage: Enter Sir JOHN RESTLESS and ROBERT, from a House in the Side Scene.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: SIR John Restless!—Sir John Restless! thou hast play'd the fool with a vengeance.—What devil whispered thee to marry such a woman?—Robert,—you have been a faithful servant in my family, Robert, and I value you.—Did your lady go out at this door here into the park, or did she go out at the street door?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: This door, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Robert, I will never live in a house again that has two doors to it.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I will give warning to my landlord instantly.—The eyes of Argus are not sufficient to watch the motions of a wife, where there is a street door, and a back door, to favour her escapes.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I wish—you will pardon my boldness, Sir,—I wish you would shake off this uneasiness that preys upon your spirits—It grieves me to the heart,—it does, indeed, Sir, to see you in this way—Banish your suspicions, Sir—you have conceived some strange aversion, I am afraid, to my lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, Robert; no aversion—in spite of me I doat upon her still—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Then why will you not think generously, Sir, of the person you love?—my lady, I dare be sworn—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Is false to me.—That embitters my whole life—I love her, and she repays me with ingratitude, with perfidy,—with falsehood,—with—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I dare be sworn, Sir, she is a woman of honour.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Robert, I have considered you as a friend in my house—Don't you betray me too—Don't justify her—don't—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Dear Sir, if you will but give me leave—you have been an indulgent master to me, and I am only concerned for your welfare—You married my lady for love, and I have heard you so warm in her praise—why will you go back from those sentiments?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, I married her for love—Oh! love! love!—What mischief dost thou not occasion in this world?—Yes, Robert; I married her for love.—When first I saw her I was not so much struck with her beauty, as with that air of an ingenuous mind that appeared in her countenance;—her features did not so much charm me with their symmetry, as that expression of sweetness, that smile that indicated affability, modesty, and compliance.—But, honest Robert, I was deceived—I was not a month married, when I saw her practising those very smiles at her glass—I saw thro' the artifice; plainly saw there was nothing natural in her manner, but all forced, all studied, put on with her head-dress—I was alarmed; I resolved to watch her from that moment, and I have seen such things—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I believe you wrong her, and wrong yourself—you build on groundless surmizes;—you make yourself unhappy, and my lady too; and by being constantly uneasy, and never shewing her the least love,—you'll forgive me, Sir,—you sill her mind with strange suspicions, and so—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Suspicions, Robert!

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; strange suspicions!—My lady finds herself treated with no degree of tenderness; she infers that, your inclinations are fixed elsewhere, and so she is become—you will pardon my blunt honesty—she is become downright jealous,—as jealous as yourself, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Oh! Robert, you are little read in the arts of women; you little know the intricacies of their conduct; the mazes thro' which they walk, shifting, turning, winding, running into devious paths, but tending all thro' a labyrinth
to the temple of Venus;—you cannot see, Robert, that all her pretences to suspect me of infidelity are merely a counter-plot to cover her own loose designs;—'tis but a gauze-covering, tho'—it is seen thro' and only serves to shew her guilt the more.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir John, I cannot see—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, Robert; I know you can't—her suspicions of me all make against her; they are but female stratagems, and yet it is but too true that she still is near my heart.—Oh! Robert, Robert, when I have watched her at a play, or elsewhere,—when I have counted her oglings, and her whisperings, her stolen glances, and her artful leer, with the cunning of her sex, she has pretended to be as watchful of me—Dissembling, false, deceitful woman!—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: And yet, I dare assure you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No more; I am not to be deceived; I know her thoroughly, and now,—now—has not she escaped out of my house, even now?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: But with no bad design.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I am the best judge of that—which way did she go?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Across the Park, Sir—that way, Sir—towards the Horse-guards—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Towards the Horse-guards!—there,—there,—there—the thing is evident;—you may go in, Robert.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Go in, I say; go in—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: There is no persuading him to his own good

Gone towards the Horse-guards!—my head aches,—my forehead burns—I am cutting my
horns—Gone towards the Horse-Guards!—I'll pursue her thither; if I find her, her usual artifice will fail her—the time, the place, will all inform against her.—Sir John! Sir John! you were a madman to marry such a woman.—

div3.stage: Enter BEVERLEY and BELLMONT, at opposite Sides.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Ha! my dear Bellmont—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Beverley!—I rejoice to see you.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well! I suppose the same cause has brought us both into the Park; both come to sigh amorous vows in the friendly gloom of yonder walk;—Belinda keeps a perpetual war of love and grief, and hope and fear in my heart—and let me see— (lays his hand on Bellmont's breast) how fares all here? I fancy my sister is a little busy here—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Busy!—she makes a perfect riot there—not one wink the whole night—Oh! Clarissa, Clarissa! her form so animated! her eyes so—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Prithee! truce; I have not leisure to attend to her praise—a sister's praise too!—Faith, the greatest merit I ever could see in Clarissa is, that she loves you freely and sincerely.

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: And to be even with you, Sir,—your Belinda, upon my soul, notwithstanding all your lavish praises, her highest perfection, in my mind, is her sensibility to the merit of my friend.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
Oh! Bellmont, don't talk prophanely—Such a girl!
Scarce can I to heav'n excuse
The devotion which I use
Unto that adored dame;
But, my dear Bellmont, tell me honestly now, do you think she has ever betrayed the least regard for me?—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: How can you, Beverley, you that have such convincing proofs, how can you ask such a question—that uneasiness of yours, that inquietude of mind—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Prithee now don't fix that character upon me—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: It is your character, my dear Beverley: and instead of enjoying the object before you, you are ever looking back to something past, or conjecturing about something to come, and are your own self-tormentor.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, no, no; don't say so; I hate the very notion of such a temper: the thing is, when a man loves tenderly as I do, sollicitude and anxiety are natural; and when Belinda's father opposes my warmest wishes—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Why yes, the good Mr. Blandford is willing to give her in marriage to me.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: The senseless old dotard!—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Thank you for the compliment!—and my father, the wise Sir William Bellmont—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Is a tyrannical, positive, headstrong—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: There again I thank you—But in short, the old couple, Belinda's father and mine, have both agreed upon the match, and they insist upon compliance from their children; so that, according to them, I am to be married off-hand to your mistress, and you and your sister, poor Clarissa, are to be left to shift for yourselves.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Racks and torment!—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p:
Racks and torment!—Seas of milk and ships of amber, man!—we are sailing to our
wished for harbour, in spite of their machinations.—I have settled the whole affair with Clarissa.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Have you?

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: I have, and to-morrow morning makes me possessor of her charms.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: My dear boy, give us your hand;—and then, thou dear rogue, and then Belinda's mine— (sings) Loll-toll-loll—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Well may you be in raptures, Sir; for here, here, here they both come—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Grace was in all her steps; heav'n in her eye;
In every gesture, dignity and love.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: A poetical reception truly!—But can't your passion inspire you to a composition of your own Mr. Beverley?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It inspires me with sentiments, Madam, which I can't find words to express.—Sucklin, Waller, Landsdown, and all our dealers in loveverses, give but a faint image of a heart touched like mine.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman! what a terrible taking you are in! But if the sonneteers cannot give an image of you, Sir, have you had recourse to a painter, as you promised me—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have Belinda, and here,—here is the humble portrait of your adorer.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well! there is a likeness—but after all, there is a better painter than this gentleman, whoever he be.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: A better!—now she is discontented (aside) where, Madam, can a better be found?—if money can purchase him—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, when he draws for money he never succeeds—But when pure inclination prompts him, then his colouring is warm indeed—He gives a portrait that endears the original.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Such an artist is worth the Indies.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You need not go so far to seek him—he has done your business already—The limner I mean is a certain little blind god, called Love, and he has stamped such an impression of you here—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam, your most obedient,—and I can tell you, that the very same gentleman has been at work for you too.—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: (who had been talking apart with Clarissa.) Oh! he has had a world of business upon his hands, for we two have been agreeing what havock he has made with us.

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: Yes, but we are but in a kind of fool's paradise here; all our schemes are but mere castle-building, which your father, Mr. Bellmont,—and my dear Belinda,—yours too are most obstinately determined to destroy.

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Why as you say, they are determined that I shall have the honour of Belinda's hand in the country-dance of matrimony.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Without considering that I may like another partner better—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And without considering that I, forlorn as I am, and my sister, there—who is as well inclined to a matrimonial game of romps as any girl in Christendom, must both of us sit down, and lead apes in hell, in spite of our strongest inclinations to mingle in the groupe.

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p:
But we have planned our own happiness, and with a little resolution we shall be successful
in the end I warrant ye.—Clarissa, my angel, let us take a turn this way, and leave that love-sick pair to themselves—they are only fit company for each other, and we can find wherewithal to entertain ourselves.—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: Ay! let us turn this way.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What are you going to leave us, Clarissa?—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: Only just sauntering into this sidewalk—we sha'nt lose one another.—

sp.speaker: BELIND.
sp.p: Oh! you are such a tender couple—you are not tired I see of saying pretty soft things to each other.—Well! well!—take your own way.—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: And if I guess right, you are glad to be left together—Belinda.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Who I?—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: You, my dear—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Not I truly—let us walk together.—

sp.speaker: CLAR.
sp.p: No, no, by no means—you shall be indulged—adieu!—we shall be within call.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: My sister is frankly in love with Bellmont—I wish Belinda would act as openly towards me—I wish she has not a lurking inclination for Bellmont. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, Sir!—Thoughtful!—Oh! I'll call Mr. Bellmont back, if that is the case.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She will call Mr. Bellmont back. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, Sir; am I to entertain you, or you me?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
Madam!—ha! ha! why you look as
if you were frightened—are you afraid of being left alone with me?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! Belinda, you know that is the happiness of my life;—but—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But what, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am afraid I have done something to offend you.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: To offend me!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, Belinda; I should have been of the party last night; I own I should; it was a sufficient inducement for me that you was to be there; it was my fault, and you I see are piqued at it.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I piqued!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I see you are; and you was so last night too—I have heard it all, and in mere resentment you directed all your discourse to Mr. Bellmont.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: If I did, it was merely accidental.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, it was deliberately done;—forgive my rash folly in refusing the invitation—I meant no manner of harm—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Who imagines you did, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Belinda, you take offence too lightly—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ha! ha! what have you taken into your head now?—this uneasiness is of your own making—I have taken nothing ill, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You could not but take it ill; but by all that's amiable about you, I meant not to incur your displeasure—forgive that abrupt answer I sent—I should have made a handsomer apology.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Apology!—what occasion was there for any thing more?—you said you was pre-engaged, did not you?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I said so; I own it, and beg your pardon—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Beg my pardon! for what? ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I only meant—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ha! ha! can you think I see any thing in your message to be offended at, Sir?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Where you were concerned, I own I should have expressed myself with more delicacy, than those hasty words, I am engaged, and can't wait upon you to-night. I should have told you that my heart was with you, though necessity dragged me another way—but this omission you resented—I could learn, since, the spirits you were in the whole evening, though I enjoyed nothing in your absence—I could hear the sallies of your wit, the sprightliness of your conversation, and on whom your eyes were fixed the whole night.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: They were fixed upon Mr. Bellmont, you think!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Ay! and fixed with delight upon him; seemed negociating the business of love before the whole company.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, whoever is your author, he has misinformed you; and let me tell you, you alarm me with these fancies, and you know I have often told you that you are of too refining a temper—you create for yourself imaginary misunderstandings, and then are ever entering into explanations—I assure you, Mr. Beverley, this watching for intelligence, from the spies and misrepresenters of conversation, betrays the symptoms of jealousy, and I would not be married to a jealous man for the world.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
Now she is seeking occasion to break off.— (aside.) Jealousy, Ma'am, can never get admission into my breast, I am of too generous
a temper; a certain delicacy I own I have; I value the opinion of my friends, and when there are circumstances of a doubtful aspect, I am glad to set things in their true light;—and surely, Belinda, if I do so with others, surely with you on whom my happiness depends to desire a favourable interpretation of my words and actions—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But these little humours may grow up, and gather into the fixed disease of jealousy at last.— (Lady Restless crosses the stage, and rings a bell at the door.) And there now,—there goes a lady who is a victim to her own fretful imagination—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Who is the lady pray?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: My lady Restless;—walk this way, and I will give you her whole character—I am not acquainted with her ladyship, but I have heard much of her—this way—this way—

sp.speaker: Lady RESTLESS
sp.p: What do these servants mean?—there is something going forward here—I will be let in or I will know the reason why— (rings again) but in the mean time, Sir John can let any body he pleases out at the street-door—I'll run up the steps here, and observe.

div3.stage: TATTLE opens the door, MARMALET follows her.

sp.speaker: TATTLE.
sp.p: Who rung this bell?—I don't see any body—and yet I am sure the bell rung.—Well, Mrs. Marmalet, you will be going, I see.—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Tattle; I must be going; I'll run across the Park, and I shall soon get to Grosvenor-Square—when shall I see you at our house?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Oh! the Lord knows when I shall be able to get out—my lady leads us all such lives—Oh! I wish I had such another place as you have of it.—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Heaven be praised! I have nothing to complain of.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: No, that you have not: Lord! when shall I get such a gown as that you have on by my lady—She will never fling off such a thing, and give it to a poor servant.—Worry, worry, worry herself, and every body else too—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: No; there is nobody stirring that way—what do I see?—a hussy coming out of my house!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Well, I must be gone, Mrs. Tattle—fare you well—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: She is dizoned out too! Madam is! why did not you open the door, Tattle, when I rung?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I came as soon as possible, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Who have you with you here?—what is your business, mistress?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: My business, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: In confusion too!—the case is plain—you come here after Sir John, I suppose—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I come after Sir John, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Guilt in her face! yes, after Sir John; and Tattle, you are in the plot against me; you were favouring her escape, were you?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I favour her escape, madam!—there is no occasion for that.—This is Mrs. Marmalet, madam, an acquaintance of mine, madam, that is come to see me—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! very fine, mistress! you bring your creatures after the vile man, do you?—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I assure you, madam, I am a very honest girl—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! I dare say so—where did you get that gown?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: La! ma'am!—I came by it honestly—my lady Conquest gave it to me—I live with my lady Conquest, madam—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What a complexion she has!—how long have you lived in London?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Three years, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: In London three years with that complexion! it can't be—but perhaps she is painted—all these creatures paint—you are all so many painted dolls (rubs her face with a white handkerchief) no—it does not come off—so, Mrs. Tattle, you bring your fresh country girls here to my house, do you?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Upon my credit, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Don't tell me—I see thro' this affair—Go you about your business, mistress, and let me never see you about my doors again—go—go—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Lord, ma'am, I shan't trouble your house—Mrs. Tattle, a good day—here's a deal to do, indeed—I have as good a house as her's to go to—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
There, there, there;—see there;—she goes off in a huff! the way with them all—ay! I see how it is, Tattle,—you false, ungrateful—that
gown was never given her by a woman—she had that from Sir John.—Where is Sir John?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Sir John an't at home, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where is he?—where is he gone?—when did he go out?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I really don't know, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Tattle, I know you fib now—But I'll sift this to the bottom.—I'll write to my lady Conquest to know the truth about that girl that was here but now.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: You will find I told you truth, madam—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Very well, Mrs. Pert,—I'll go and write this moment,—send Robert to me to give me an account of his master—Sir John, Sir John, you will distract me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ay! but that quickness, and that extreme sensibility is what I am afraid of.—I positively would not have a jealous husband for the world—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: By heaven! no earthly circumstance shall ever make me think injuriously of you.—Jealousy!—ha! ha!—it is the most ridiculous passion—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You may laugh, Sir; but I know your over-refining temper too well, and I absolutely will have it in our marriage-articles, that I must not be plagued with your suspicions.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I subscribe, ma'am—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
I will have no enquiries where I am going to visit; no following me from place to place; and if we should chance to meet, and you should perceive a man of wit, or a pretty fellow,
speaking to me, I will not have you fidgetting about on your chair, knitting your brow, and looking at your watch—My dear, is it not time to go home?—my love, the coach is waiting:—and then, if you are prevailed upon to stay, I will not have you converse with a "yes, Sir," and a "no, Sir," for the rest of the evening, and then wrangle with me in the chariot all the way home, and not be commonly civil to me for the rest of the night—I positively will have none of this—.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Agreed, ma'am, agreed—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: And then you shan't tell me you are going out of town, and then sneak in privately to the play, or to Ranelagh, merely to be a spy upon me—and I positively will admit no curiosity about my letters—if you were to open a letter of mine, I should never forgive you—I do verily believe, if you were to open my letters I should hate you—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I subscribe to every thing you can ask—you shall have what female friends you please; loose your money to whom you please; dance with what beau you please; ride out with whom you please; go to what china shop you please; and, in short, do what you please, without my attempting to bribe your footman, or your maid to—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! lud! Oh! lud! that is in the very strain of jealousy—Heaven deliver me!—there is my father yonder, and Sir William Bellmont with him—Fly—this instant, fly, Mr. Beverley, down that walk—any where—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You promise then—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
Don't talk to me now—what would you be at?—I am yours, and only yours; unalterably
so—Fly—Mr. Beverley, be gone, and leave me—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I obey, madam—I am gone.

sp.speaker: BELINDA.
sp.p: Now are they putting their wise heads together to thwart all my schemes of happiness—but love, imperious love, will have it otherwise—

div3.stage: Enter Mr. BLANDFORD, and Sir WILLIAM.

sp.speaker: Mr. BLAND.
sp.p: Sir William, since we have agreed upon every thing—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Why yes, Mr. Blandford, I think every thing is settled—

sp.speaker: Mr. BLAND.
sp.p: Why then we have only to acquaint the young people with our intentions, and so conclude the affair—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: That is all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. BLAND.
sp.p: As to my girl, I don't mind her nonsense about Beverley—she must do as I will have her.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: And my son too, he must follow my directions.—As to his telling me of his love for Clarissa, it is all a joke to me—Children must do as their parents will have them.—

sp.speaker: Mr. BLAND.
sp.p: Ay! ay! so they must; and so they shall—hey! here is my daughter—So Belinda!—well, my girl, Sir William and I have agreed, and so you are to prepare for marriage, that's all—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Marriage with Mr. Beverley, Sir?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Mr. Beverley!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You know you encouraged him yourself, Sir—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p:
Well, well! I have changed my mind on that head—my friend, Sir William, here offers
you his son—do as I would have you—have a care, Belinda—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: But, madam, I will be obeyed—You don't like him, you say—but I like him—and that's sufficient for you—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: And so it is, Mr. Blandford;—if my son pretended to have a will of his own, I should let him know to the contrary—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: And can you, Sir William, against our inclination force us both?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, Belinda; don't provoke me—What makes you from home?—go your ways back to Queen's-Square directly, and settle your mind; for I tell you once for all I will have my own way.—Come, Sir William, we will step to the lawyer's chambers.—Go home, Belinda, and be observant of my commands.—Come along, Sir William—what did you say?—you mutiny, do you?—don't provoke me—You know, Belinda, I am an odd sort of a man when provok'd—Look ye here—mind what I say; I won't reason with you about the matter; my power is absolute, and if you offer to rebel, you shall have no husband at all with my consent—I'll cut you off with a shilling; I'll see you starve—beg an alms—live miserable—die wretched—in short, suffer any calamity without the least compassion from me—if I should find you an undutiful girl at last—so there's one word for all—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
What will become of me?—his inhumanity overcomes me quite—I can never consent—the very sight of this picture is enough to forbid it—Oh! Beverley,—you are the master
of my heart—I'll go this instant—and—heavens! I can scarce move—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No tidings of her far or near—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: How I tremble!—I shall fall—no help—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What do I see!—a young lady in distress!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh!—(faints in his arms, and drops the picture.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: She is fallen into a fit—Would my servants were in the way—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where can this barbarous man be gone to?—Ha!—under my very window!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: How cold she is!—quite cold— (lays his hand to her cheek)

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: How familiar he is with her!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And yet she looks beautiful still—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Does she so?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Her eyes open—how lovely they look!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Traitor!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Her cheek begins to colour—well, young lady, how fare you now?—my dear.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: My dear, too—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Heavens! where am I?—In a strange gentleman's arms all this time!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Repose yourself there, or will you step into my house?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
No, truly, shan't she—vile man!—But I will spoil your sport—I will come
down to you directly, and flash confusion in your face—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Where do you live, madam?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: In Queen's-Square, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I will wait upon you—trust yourself with me—you look much better now—Lean on my arm—there, there, I will conduct you—
Now I'll make one among ye.—ha! fled! gone! which way?—is not that he, yonder?—no—he went into my house, I dare say, as I came down stairs—Tattle, Tattle, Robert,—will nobody answer—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where is Sir John?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: La! ma'am, how should I know?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Did not he go in this moment?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: No, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: To be sure you will say so—I'll follow him thro' the world, or I'll find him out—so, so—what is here?—this is her picture, I suppose—I will make sure of this at least—this will discover her to me, tho' she has escaped now—The cruel, false, deceitful man!

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Poor lady! I believe her head is turned, for my part.—Well! I am determined I'll look out for another place, that's a sure thing I will.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: ROBERT, where is your lady?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: In her own room, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Any body with her?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I can't say, Sir—my lady is not well—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Not well! fatigued with rioting about this town, I suppose—how long has she been at home?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: About an hour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: About an hour!—very well, Robert, you may retire— (Exit Robert)—now will I question her closely—so—so—so—she comes, leaning on her maid—finely dissembled!—finely dissembled!—But this pretended illness shall not shelter her from my strict enquiry—Soft a moment!—If I could overhear what passes between 'em, it might lead to the truth—I'll work by stratagem—Oh! the hypocrite! how she acts her part!—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: How are you now, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Somewhat better, Tattle—reach that chair—Tattle, tell me honestly, does that girl live with Lady Conquest?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: She does, madam, upon my veracity.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Very well! you will be obstinate, I see, but I shall know the truth presently; I shall have an answer from her ladyship, and then all will come out.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: You will hear nothing, Ma'am, but what I have told you already.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Tattle, Tattle, I took you up in the country in hopes gratitude would make you my friend—but you are as bad as the rest of them—conceal all you know, do;—it is of very little consequence—I now see through the whole affair—though it is the picture of a man—yet I am not to be deceived—I understand it all.—This is some former gallant—the creature gave this to Sir John, as a proof that she had no affection for any but himself.—What art he must have had to induce her to this!—I have found him out at last—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What does she say?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I have seen enough to convince me what a man he is—the fate of us poor women is hard—we all wish for husbands, and they are the torments of our lives.—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: There is too much truth in what you say, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You join her, do you, Mrs. Iniquity?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What a pity it is, Tattle, that poor women should be under severer restraints than the men are!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You repine for want of freedom, do you?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
Cruel laws of wedlock!—The tyrant-husband may triumph in his infidelity,
may securely trample upon all laws of decency and order, and it redounds to his credit—gives him a fashionable air of vice, while a poor woman is obliged to submit to his cruelty—and remains tied to him for life—even though she has reason to entertain a mortal hatred for him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! very well argued, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What a pity it is, Tattle, that we cannot change our husbands, as we do our ear-rings or our gloves!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: There is a woman of spirit!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Tattle! will you own the truth to me about that girl?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I really have told you the truth, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You won't discover, I see—very well!—you may go down stairs—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I assure your ladyship—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Go down stairs—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Would I had never seen my husband's face!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I am even with you—I have as good wishes for you, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: This picture here—Oh the base man!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The picture of her gallant, I suppose.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: This is really a handsome picture—what a charming countenance!—It is perfumed I fancy—the scent is agreeable—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! the jade, how eagerly she kisses it!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Why had not I such a dear, dear man, instead of the brute, the monster—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Monster!—She does not mince the matter, but speaks plain downright English—I must contain my rage, and steal upon her meditations—so—so—so—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: There is no falshood in this look.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: (Looking over her shoulder.) Oh! what a handsome dog she has chosen for herself!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: With you, I could be for ever happy—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You could, could you? (Snatches the picture.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: (Screams out.) Mercy on me!—Oh! is it you, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now, madam, now false one, have I caught you?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You are come home at last, I find, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My lady Restless, my lady Restless, what can you say for yourself now?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What can I say for myself, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! Madam! this picture—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, that picture.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Will be an evidence—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Of your shame Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Of my shame!—'tis very true what she says;—yes, madam, it will be an evidence of my shame; I feel that but too sensibly;—but—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You own it then, do you?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Own it! I must own it, madam; though confusion cover me, I must own it;—it is what you have deserved at my hands—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
I deserve it, Sir John!—but find excuses if you will—cruel, cruel man!—to make
me this return at last—I cannot bear it—Oh! oh! (Cries.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! you may weep; but your tears are lost; they will fall without effect.—I now renounce you for ever—this picture will justify me to the wide world; it will shew what a base woman you have been.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What does the man mean?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The picture of your gallant, madam!—the darling of your amorous hours,—who gratifies your luxurious appetites abroad, and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Scurrilous wretch! Oh! Sir, you are at your old stratagem I find,—recrimination, you think, will serve your turn.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It is a pity you know, madam, that a woman should be tied to a man for life, even though she has a mortal hatred for him.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Artful hypocrite!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: That she can't change her husband as she does her ear-rings or her gloves.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Po! Sir John, this is your old device, this won't avail you.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Had the original of this fallen to your lot, you could kiss the picture for ever.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! Sir John.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You can gloat upon it, madam, glue your very lips to it.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Shallow artifice!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: With him you could be for ever happy.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: This is all in vain, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Had such a dear, dear man fallen to your lot, instead of the brute, the monster—Am I a monster?—I am,—and you have made me so—the world shall know your infamy.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! brave it out, Sir, brave it out to the last—harmless, innocent man!—you have nothing to blush for, nothing to be ashamed of—you have no intrigues, no private amours abroad—I have not seen any thing, not I—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Madam, I have seen, and I now see your paramour.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! that air of confidence will be of great use to you, Sir—for you have no convenient to meet you under my very window, to loll softly in your arms—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Hey! how!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Her arm thrown carelessly round your neck—your hand tenderly applied to her cheek.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: S'death! that's unlucky—she will turn it against me. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! you are in confusion, are you, Sir?—but why should you? you meant no harm—You are safe with me, my dear—will you step into my house, my love?—yes, Sir, you would fain bring her into my very house—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My Lady Restless, this evasion is mean and paultry—you beheld a young lady in distress.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! I know it, Sir,—and you, tender-hearted man, could caress her out of meer compassion;—gaze wantonly on her out of charity, and, out of pure benevolence of disposition, convey her to some convenient dwelling—Oh! Sir John, Sir John—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Madam, this well-acted passion—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Don't imagine she has escaped me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Oh! you may talk and rave, ma'am; but depend upon it, I shall spare no pains to do
myself justice on this occasion—nor will I rest till—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! fie upon you, Sir John; these artifices—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN
sp.p: Nor will I rest, madam, until I have found, by means of this instrument here in my hand, who your darling is—I will go about streight—ungrateful, treacherous woman!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Yes, go now, under that pretext, in pursuit of your licentious pleasures.—This ever has been his scheme to cloak his wicked practices—abandoned man!—To face me down too, after what my eyes so plainly beheld—I wish I could wring that secret out of Tattle—I'll step to my own room directly, and try by menaces, by wheedling, by fair means, by foul means, by every means, to wrest it from her.

div3.stage: Enter Sir JOHN, and ROBERT after him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Come hither, Robert—look at this picture—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Let me watch his countenance—well! well!—dost thou know it, Robert?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: 'Tis a mighty handsome picture, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: A handsome picture!— (Aside.)

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: The finest lady in the land need not desire a handsomer man, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: How well he knows the purposes of it!—well! well! honest Robert, tell me,—well—who is it?—tell me—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
You know whose picture that is—
I know you do—well! well! who—who—who is it?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I don't know—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Not know!—but I am convinced you know—so own the truth—don't be a villain—don't—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: As I am an honest man, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Be an honest man then, and tell me—did you never see such a smooth faced, fiery eyed, warm-complexioned, taper young fellow here about my house?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Never, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. JOHN.
sp.p: Not with my wife!—to drink chocolate of a morning, tea of an evening—come, honest Robert—I'll give you a lease of a good farm—come, what say you?—a lease for your life—well! well!—you may take your wife's life into the bargain—well!—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir John, I never saw—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I'll add your child's life—come speak out—your own life, your wife's life, and your child's—now! now! a lease for three lives you have—now, Robert!—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: As I hope for mercy I never saw any such person.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Robert, Robert, you are bribed by my wife—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: No, as I am a sinner, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And the worst of sinners you will be, if you are a confederate in this plot against my peace and honour.—Reflect on that Robert.

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: Pray does not Sir John Restless live somewhere hereabout?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He does, friend; what is your business with him?

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: My business is with his lady—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I guessed as much. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: I have a letter here for my lady Restless, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: A letter for my lady!—from whom, pray?—

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: From my lord Conquest.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My lord Conquest! very well, friend—you may give the letter to me—I am Sir John Restless—that there is my house—let me have the letter—I will take care of it.

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: I was ordered to deliver it into my lady's own hand.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The devil you was—I must have the letter—I'll buy it of the rascal— (aside)—here take this for your trouble, friend, (gives him money) and I'll take care of the letter—

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: I humbly thank your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now—now—now—let me see what this is—now my lady Restless—now false-one, now— (reads.)

Madam,
My lady Conquest being gone into the country for a few days, I have judged it proper to send a speedy answer to yours, and to assure you, for your peace of mind, that you need not entertain the least suspicion of Marmalet, my lady's woman. She has lived some years in our family, and I know her by experience to be an honest trusty girl, and one that would not make mischief between your ladyship and Sir John.
I have the honour to be, Madam, your very humble servant,
CONQUEST.

So! so! so!—Marmalet is a trusty girl!—one that will not make mischief between man and wife!—that is to say, now that she will discover nothing against my lady Restless!—for her peace of mind he lets madam know all this too!—she may go on boldly now; for my lady Conquest is gone into the country, Marmalet is trusty, and my lord has given her the most speedy notice—Very well! very well!—proofs thicken upon proofs—Shall I go directly and challenge his lordship?—no—no—that won't do—Watch him closely, that will do better—If I could have a word in private with the maid—Robert,—Robert—come hither—step to my lord Conquest's—but with caution proceed—Enquire there for Marmalet, the maid.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I know her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He knows her—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: She visits our Tattle, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Visits our Tattle!—it is a plain case— (aside)—Enquire for that girl—but with caution, tho'—and tell her to meet me privately—unknown to any body—in the dusk of the evening—down in the Bird-Cage walk, yonder.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And don't let Tattle see her—Tattle has engaged her in her mistress's interest—I see how it is—don't let any of my servants see her—go directly, Robert. Now shall I judge what regard you have for me—But, hark ye, Robert!—Come hither! a word with you—should it be known that this girl converses with me—should my lady have the least item of it, they are then upon their guard—You must be cautious, therefore—let her come wrapped up in darkness—concealed from every observer with a mask on—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: A mask, Sir John—won't that make her be remark'd the more?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, let her come masked; I will make every thing sure—Robert, bring this about for me, and I am your friend for ever—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I will do my endeavour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I'll now take a turn round the Park, and try if I can find the minion this picture belongs to—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, they had almost surpriz'd us—but at sight of her father, Belinda gave me the word, and away I darted down towards the canal, yonder—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Was Sir William with him then?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes; they had been plotting our destruction together—But we shall out-officer them, it is to be hoped, my boy.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, and it is also to be feared that we shall not.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Hey! you alarm me—no new mine sprung!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, nothing new; but the old story—The old folks are determined;—at the turning of yonder corner they came both full tilt upon Clarissa, and me—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well, and how! what passed?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why they were scarcely civil to your sister. Sir William fixed his surly eye upon me for a time, then calling me to him, Sir, says he, you will run counter to my will, I see—you will be ever dangling after that girl—But, Mr. Blandford and I have agreed upon the match,—and then he peremptorily commanded me to take my leave of her that moment.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And did you so?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And did you so?—how can you ask such a question? Sir, says I, I must see the lady home, and so off I marched, arm in arm, with her, my father bawling after me, and I bowing to him, Sir, your humble servant, I wish you a good morning, Sir.—He continued calling out,—I kissed my hand to him,—and so we made our escape.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And where have you left her?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: At home; at your house.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well! and do ye both continue in the same mind; is to-morrow to be your weddingday?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now are you conjuring up a thousand horrid fancies to torment yourself with—But don't be alarmed, my dear Beverley—I shall leave you your Belinda, and content myself with the honour of being your brother-in-law.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, the honour will be to me—But uneasy!—ha! ha!—no—no—I am not uneasy, nor shall I ever be so again—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I wish you would keep that resolution—where do you dine?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Will you dine with me?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I can't; 'tis club-day—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Faith, so it is—I'll attend you—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That's right; let us turn towards the Mall, and saunter there till dinner—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, I can't go that way yet—I must enquire how Belinda does, and what her father said to her; for I have not seen her since we parted in the morning.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
And now, according to custom, you will make her an apology for leaving her, when there was an absolute necessity for it, and you'll
fall to an explanation of circumstances that require no explanation at all, and refine upon things, and—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Nay, if you begin with your raillery, I am off—your servant—a l'honneur—

Poor Beverley!—Tho' a handsome fellow, and of agreeable talents, he has such a strange diffidence in himself, and such a solicitude to please, that he is every moment of his life most ingeniously elaborating his own uneasiness.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Not yet, not yet; nobody like it as yet—ha!—who is that hovering about my house?—if that should be he now!—I'll examine him nearer—Pray, Sir—what the devil shall I say?—Pray, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I beg pardon for troubling you, Sir—but pray what o'clock is it by your watch?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: By my watch, Sir!—I'll let you know in a moment—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Let me examine him now— (looks at him, and then at the picture.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Egad, I am afraid my watch is not right—it must be later—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It is not like him— (comparing them both)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: It does not go, I am afraid— (puts it to his ear.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The eye—no!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, Sir, by my watch it wants a quarter of three.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It is not he—and yet—no—no—no—I am still to seek—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Hip! Bellmont—well overtaken—a word with you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Here comes another;—they are all swarming about my house—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have seen her; I have seen Belinda, my boy—she will be with Clarissa in the Park immediately after dinner, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I want to see his face; this may be the original.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Her father has been rating her in his usual manner; but your marriage with my sister will settle every thing.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I'll walk round him (sings) Loll toll loll— (locks at him)—ha! it has his air— (sings) Loll toll loll,—and it has his eye—Loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Prithee, Bellmont, don't be such a danggling lover, but consummate at once, prithee do, for the sake of your friends.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It has his nose for all the world.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I'll tell you what, Beverley, do you spirit your sister up to keep her resolution, and tomorrow puts you out of all pain—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: —Loll toll loll—it has his complexion—the same glowing, hot, amorous complexion—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Who is this gentleman walking here?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Faith, I don't know—an odd fellow he seems to be—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Loll toll loll—it has his shoulders—Loll toll loll—ay, and I fancy the mole upon
the cheek too—I wish I could view him nearer—Loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: The man seems mad, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Begging your pardon, Sir—Pray (looking at him and the picture)—Pray, Sir, can you tell whether we shall have a Spanish war?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Not I, truly; did you ever see such an odd fellow, Bellmont?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: He has been talking to me too: he is too well dressed for a poet.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Not, if he has had a good subscription.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He has the mole sure enough—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Let us step this way—I have more to say to you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! he wants to sneak off—Guilt! guilt! conscious guilt!—I'll make sure of him tho'—pray, Sir,—I beg your pardon—is not your name Wildair?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, Sir, Beverley, at your service.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Have you no relation of that name?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You are very like a gentleman of that name—a friend of mine, whose picture I have here—will you give me leave just to— compares him with the picture.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: An odd adventure this, Bellmont.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Very odd, indeed.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Do you find any likeness, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Your head a little more that way, if you please—ay! ay! it is he—'tis a plain case; this is my man, or rather,—this is my wife's man—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Did you ever know any thing like this?—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Never—ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: They are both laughing at me—ay! and I shall be laught at by the whole town, pointed at, hooted at, and gazed at—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What do I see?—s'death, the setting of that picture is like what I gave Belinda.—Zoons! if it is the same—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He makes his approach,—and means, I suppose, to snatch it out of my hand—But I'll be before-hand with him,—and so into my pocket it goes—There, lie safe there—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Zoons! he puts it up in a hurry—will you be so good, Sir, as to favour me with a—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, I wish you a good day—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: With a sight of that picture for a moment—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The picture, Sir—Po!—a mere daub—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Mere curiosity, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: It is not worth your seeing—I wish you a good day.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I should take it as a favour—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: A paltry thing—I have not a moment to spare—my family waiting dinner—Sir, I wish you a good morning— (runs into his house.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Death and fire! Bellmont, my picture—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! no—no such thing—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But I am sure of it—if Belinda—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What, relapsing into uneasiness and suspicion again!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I have reason to be uneasy—she slights me, disdains me,—treats me with contempt—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But I tell you, that unhappy temper of yours—Prithee, man, leave teazing yourself, and let us adjourn to dinner—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, Sir; I shan't dine at all—I am not well—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ridiculous! how can you be so absurd?—I'll bett you twenty pounds that is not your picture—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Done; I take it—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: With all my heart; and I'll tell you what, if it be yours, I will give you leave to be as jealous of her as you please—Come, now let us to dinner—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I attend you—in the evening we shall know the truth—if it be that I gave Belinda—she is false, and I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN,
sp.p: There he goes—there he goes—the destroyer of my peace and happiness!—I'll follow him, and make sure that he has given me his name rightly,—and then, my Lady Restless, I have done with you for ever.

sp.speaker: BELINDA.
sp.p: BUT have you really fixed every thing, Clarissa?

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Positively, and to-morrow morning makes me his.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: To-morrow morning!

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Yes, to-morrow morning I release Mr. Bellmont from his fetters, and resign my person to him.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Why, that is what all we poor women, after all the victories of our charms, all the triumphs of our beauty, and all the murders of our eyes, must come to at last.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well, and in that we but imitate the men. Don't we read of them conquering whole kingdoms, and then submitting at last to be governed by the vanquished.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very true, Clarissa; and upon my word I think you are a heroine equal in fame to any of them; nay superior, for your scheme, I take it, is not to unpeople the world—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Prithee, Belinda, don't talk so wildly; for, to tell you the truth, now that I have settled the affair, I begin to be alarmed at what I have done.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! dear, dear affectation!—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Actually now, positively, I am terrified to death.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—to be sure—our sex must play its tricks, and summon up all its fantastic train of doubts and fears—but courage, my dear, don't be frightened, for the same sex within that heart of yours will urge you on, and never let you be at rest, till you have procured yourself a tyrant for life.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: A tyrant, Belinda! I think more generously of Mr. Bellmont, than to imagine he will usurp to himself an ill use of his power—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: To deal candidly with you, I am of your opinion—but, tell me now, a'n't I a very good girl, to resign such a man to you?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Why, indeed, I must confess the obligation.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ay! but to resign him for one, whose temper does not promise I shall live under so mild a government.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: How do you mean?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Beverley's strange caprices, suspicions, and unaccountable whimsies, are enough to alarm one upon the brink of matrimony.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well, I vow I can't help thinking, Belinda, that you are a little subject to vain surmises and suspicions yourself.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Come now, you are an insincere girl; you know I am of a temper too generous, too open—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: I grant all that, but by this constant repetition of the same doubts, I should not wonder to see you most heartily jealous of him—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Jealous!—oh heavens!—jealous indeed!—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well, I say no more; and as to my brother, here he comes, and let him speak for himself.—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, upon my soul, Beverley, you make me laugh at you—but come, there's an end of that matter—Ladies your most obedient—I hope we have not transgressed our time.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Not in the least; you are both very exact—true as the dial to the sun.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: (In a peevish manner.) Although it be not shone upon.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Although it be not shone upon, Mr. Beverley!—why with that dejected air, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! lord! you two are going to commence wrangling lovers again—a-propos, Belinda—now Beverley, you shall see—be so good, ma'am, as to let me see this gentleman's picture.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: His picture! what can you want it for?—you shall have it— (searching her pocket.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now, Beverley, do you confess how wrong you have been?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Why faith I begin to think I was wrong—say not a word to her—she'll never forgive me else. (Apart.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: It is not in that pocket—it must be here— (searches the other.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You have been sad company, on account of this strange suspicion.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I own it; let it drop; say no more.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
Well! I protest and vow—what can
become of it? come, gentlemen, this is some trick of yours—you have it among ye—Mr. Bellmont, Mr. Beverley—pray return it—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, ma'am, it is no trick of ours— (angrily.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: As I live and breathe I have not got it.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What think you now, Bellmont?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She'll find it presently, man; don't shew your humours, be upon your guard; you'll undo yourself else—Clarissa, shall you and I saunter down this walk?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: My brother seems out of humour,—what's the matter?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I'll tell you presently—let us step this way.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, I declare upon my honour I don't know what is come of this odious picture—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: This odious picture!—Oh! Belinda.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You may look grave, Sir, but I have it not.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I know you have not, ma'am; and don't imagine—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Imagine! what do you mean?—imagine what?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Don't imagine that I am to be led blindfold as you please.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! heavens! with what gravity that was said!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am not to be deceived; I can see all around me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You can?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I can, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, and how do you like your prospect?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! you begin to banter—but that picture I have seen this day in the hands of another—the gentleman to whom you gave it.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: To whom I gave it!—have a care, Sir; this is another symptom of your jealous temper.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But I tell you, madam, I saw it in his hand.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Who is the gentleman?—what's his name?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: That I can't say—I—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, upon my word you are making yourself very ridiculous in this matter—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You may laugh, madam, but it is no laughing matter, I assure you—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! brave—follow your own notions—I gave it away—I have scorned your present—ha! ha!—poor Mr. Beverley!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I don't doubt you, ma'am, I believe you did give it away.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Mighty well, Sir,—think so if you please—I shall leave you to your own imagination—it will find wherewithal to entertain you—ha! ha! your servant, Sir,—yonder I see Clarissa and Mr. Bellmont—I will join them this instant—your servant, Sir,—amuse yourself with your own fancies—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEVERLEY
sp.p:
Damnation!—I can't tell what to make of this.—She carries it of with an air of confidence; and yet if that be my picture, which I saw this
morning, then it is plain I am only laught at by her—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Observe him now—let us walk by him without taking any notice of him—and so—let us talk of any thing rather than be silent—What a charming evening!

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: And how gay the park looks!—mind the gentleman!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Take no notice; I beg you won't—Suppose we were to shew ourselves in the Mall, Clarissa, and walk our charms there, as the French express it!—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—Beverley!—what fixed in contemplation!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I beg—I chuse to be alone, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEL. BELIN. CLA.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Pshaw! foolish!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! for heaven's sake—let us indulge the gentleman—let us leave him to himself, and his ill humouts—this way—this way—you shall go home and have your tea with me—Mr. Beverley (she kisses her hand to him at some distance, and laughs at him) your servant, Sir—I wish you a good evening—your servant, Sir—

Zoons! I can't bear all this—if she has parted with the picture—if she has given it away—but she may only have lent it, or she may have
lost it—but even that, even that is an injury to me—why should she not be more careful of it?—I will know the bottom of it—that's the house the gentleman went into—I'll wait on him directly—but they are watching me—I'll walk off another way, to elude their observation—ay! ay! you may laugh, ma'am, but I shall find you out.

head.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment at Sir John's.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where are you going, Sir?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: To my master's room, madam, to leave these cloaths there.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Stay, Sir;—stay a moment (searches the pockets)—Where are his letters?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Letters, my lady!—I know of no letters—I never touch his pockets—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I guessed you would say so—you are Sir John's agent—the conductor of his schemes.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I, madam!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You, Sir,—you are his secretary for love affairs.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I collect his rents, my lady, and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, I am not to be deceived—I know you for my enemy.—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Enemy, ma'am!—I am sure, as far as a poor servant dare, I am a friend to both—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Then tell me honestly, have not you conveyed his letters out of my way?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, not I—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Then he has done it himself—artful man!—I never can find a line after him—where did you go for him this morning?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: This morning!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Ay! this morning—I know he sent you somewhere—Where was it?—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Upon my word, my lady—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—I see how it is—you are all bent against me—I shall never be at rest till every servant in this house is of my own chusing.—Is Tattle come home yet?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Where can she be gadding about? Hark!—I hear a rap at the door—this is Sir John, I suppose—stay, let me listen—I don't know that voice—who can it be—some of his libertine company, I suppose—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: My lady, if you will believe me—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, man—let me hear—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Indeed, madam—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, I say!—won't you hold your tongue?—go about your business, Sir, go about your business—What does he say? (listening) I can't hear a word—Who's below there?

div3.stage: Enter TATTLE, with a Capuchin on.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: So Mrs. Tattle—who is that at the door?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: A gentleman, madam, speaking to William.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And where have you been, mistress?—How dare you go out without my leave—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Dear, my lady, don't be angry with me—I was so terrified about what happened in the morning; and your ladyship was in such a perilous taking about it, that I went to desire Mrs. Marmalet would justify herself and me—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! very well, Mrs. Busy-Body—you have been there, have you?—You have been to frame a story among yourselves, have you, and to hinder me from discovering?—But I'll go to my Lady Conquest myself—I have had no answer to my letter, and 'tis you have occasioned it—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Dear, my lady, if you will but give me leave—I have been doing you the greatest piece of service—I believe, in my conscience, there is something in what you suspect about Sir John—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Do you?—why?—how?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: I have seen Mrs. Marmalet, and I have made such a discovery—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Have you Tattle?—what?—speak—tell me—what is it?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Robert has been there, madam, with a message from Sir John, who wants to see her in the evening; and he has desired—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Blessings on you, Tattle—well—go on—tell me all—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What do you want, Sir?—who called you?—go about your business—

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Madam, there is a gentleman wants to speak with Sir John about a picture—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I had forgot me—it was he rapped at the door, I suppose—

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: About a picture!—this may lead to some further discovery—desire the gentleman to step up stairs— (Exit Servant)—and so Tattle, Robert has been there—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And Sir John wants to speak with Marmalet in the evening, and has desired—Oh! the base man!—what has he desired?—now he is discovered—what has he desired?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: He has desired, ma'am—the poor girl does not know what to make of it—She is very sober and discreet, I assure you, ma'am—he has desired, ma'am, in the dusk of the evening, that Mrs. Marmalet will come and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: How unlucky this is?—the gentleman is coming—I have a mind not to see him—and yet I will too—Tattle, do you step to my room; as soon as he goes, I will come to you, and hear all in private.— (Exit Tattle) In the dusk of the evening he desires to see her—abandoned wretch!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I wanted a word with Sir John Restless, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: About a picture, the servant tells me, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, madam, a picture I had given to a lady; and however insignificant in itself, it is to me of the highest consequence, as it may conduce to the explanation of an affair, in which the happiness of my life is concerned.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: The lady is young?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And handsome?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: In the highest degree; my heart is devoted to her; and I have reason to suspect, that a present from me is not of so much value as I could wish.—To be plain, ma'am, I imagine she has given the picture away.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Look-ye there now!—my suspicions are just.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Your suspicions, madam!—did you suspect it was given to Sir John Restless?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What I know of the matter shall be no secret to you—Pray, Sir, have you spoke to the lady on this head?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have, but she knows nothing of the matter; she has lost it,—she has mislaid it,—she can give no account of it—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: She has given it to Sir John, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Given it to him?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Given it to him, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Then I have no further doubt.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam, I would not hurt your peace of mind; I would not give you impressions of Sir John, that may—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, stand upon no ceremony with him; an injurious, false, licentious man!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Is that his character?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Notoriously: he has made me miserable; false to his marriage vows, and warm in the pursuit of his pleasures abroad!—I have not deserved it of him—Oh! Sir John! Sir John! Oh!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She weeps; the case is plain, and I am undone—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what is the lady's name?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda Blandford.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Belinda Blandford!—I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, have you ever seen her?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Seen her, Sir!—yes, I have seen too much of her.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You alarm me, madam—you have seen nothing unhandsome, I hope—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I don't know what you call unhandsome, Sir.—But, pray, what ought one to think of a young lady thrown familiarly into a gentleman's arms?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: In his arms, madam!—Sir John's arms!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: In Sir John's!—in open day;—in the Park;—under my very window;—most familiarly, wantonly reclining in his very arms.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! heavens!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: He clasping her with equal freedom round the waist—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: False, false Belinda!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Both interchanging fond mutual glances—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! madam, the whole is come to light, and I thank you for the discovery, tho' I am ruined by it—But give me leave—is all this certain?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: There can be no doubt, Sir, these eyes beheld their amorous meeting.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Saw it yourself?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Yes, all, all, Sir—Sir John, I know, is capable of any thing, and you know what to think of Belinda, as you call her.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! madam, I have long had reason to suspect.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You have, Sir?—then the whole affair is plain enough.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It is so—I meant an honourable connection with her;—but—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: But you see, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, I see, madam—you are sure Sir John has this picture?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sure, Sir!—it is your own picture—I had it in my hands but a moment, and he flew with ardor, with impetuosity, like a fury flew to it, and recovered it from me—what could be the meaning of that, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: The meaning is too plain.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And then, Sir, when charged and pressed home with his guilt, most hypocritically he pretended to believe it the portrait of some favourite of mine—But you know, Sir, how that is—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! madam, I can justify you—ha! ha! that is but a poor evasion, and confirms me the more in my opinion—and I humbly take my leave—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir, I am glad you have had the good luck to speak to me about this affair;—and, if any other circumstances come to your knowledge, I shall take it as a favour if you will acquaint me with them—for, indeed, Sir, I am very unhappy—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam, I am in gratitude bound to you, and my best services, you shall ever command—Madam, your most obedient—Oh! Belinda! Belinda!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p:
Now, Sir John—how will you be able to confront these stubborn facts?—You
are now seen thro' all your disguises—detected in your true colours—Tattle within here, has fresh proofs against you, and your man Robert, and all of you,—I must hear that whole story directly—

div3.head: SCENE, the Park.

sp.p: Yes, yes,—he told me his name honestly enough—Beverley is his name—and my lady Restless, now your gallant, your paramour, is known—What do I see?—By all my wrongs, the very man again!—coming out of my house before my face—

div3.stage: BEVERLEY and ROBERT come out of the House.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: There, friend, there is something for your trouble.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: I thank your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He bribes my servant too;—and the fellow takes it—Both in their trade; both in their trade!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Could I have suspected her of such treachery—Zoons! I take that to be Sir John Restless.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This is he to whom I have so many obligations.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well encountered, Sir—your servant, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My servant, Sir!—I rather take it you are my lady's servant.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
You, if I don't mistake, Sir John, are a pretty general servant of the ladies.—Pray,
Sir, have not you a picture of mine in your pocket?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: That, I suppose, you have heard from my good lady within here—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and I have heard a great deal more from my lady.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I don't in the least doubt it.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I do not mean to work myself up into any choler about such a trifling bauble—since the lady has thought proper to give it to you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Do her justice, pray; she did not give it; so far she was true to you—I took it from her, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And that shews you are upon free and easy terms with her;—it is of no manner of consequence to me; I despise it, and you are welcome to make what use you will of it.—This, I will only say, that you have made me miserable.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What, I have interrupted your happiness?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You have.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And no doubt you think it cruel of me so to do.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Call it by what name you will,—you have ruined me with the woman I doated on to distraction.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: A candid declaration!—and so, Sir, you doated on her, and never reflected that you were doing me the least injury?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Injury!—I promise you, Sir, I will never injure you again, and so you may set your mind at peace, for I here declare, I never will hold farther intercourse with her—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! that is too late for me; I have now done with her myself—you are very welcome to the lady, Sir—you may take her home with you as soon as you please; I have done with her, I forswear her, and so I shall tell my lady this moment— (going.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: That will make her ladyship happy, no doubt—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, I dare say you know it will—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She told me as much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: She did!—why then you may depend I shall keep my word, and my lady may depend upon it too—and that I hope, with all my heart, will make you happy, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It won't indeed, Sir—I resign her for ever—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What, are you tired of her—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I loath her, detest her, hate her as much as I ever loved her.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And so do I too, I assure you—and so I shall tell my lady this very instant—your servant, Sir—and, if I can find proof sufficient, you shall hear of me, I promise you, Sir— (aside.)

sp.speaker: BEVERLEY.
sp.p: Ay! she has been connected with him, till she has pall'd his very appetite—s'death, I'll seek her this moment, upbraid her with her falshood,—and even so—by heavens! I shall do it with regret—for even now I feel a tug at my heartstring—but were I to be torn piece-meal, this shall be our last interview—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Alas a-day! poor soul! see where he takes his melancholy walk—did not I tell you, Clarissa, that the stricken deer could not quit this place?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: And did not I tell you, Belinda, that you could not keep away from the pursuit?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Pray, ma'am, do you want to be in at the death, or do you mean to bring the poor thing to life again?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I!—what do you mean?—you bring me this way—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well! if that is the case, we had as good go home to your house, for I want my tea—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Po! not yet—it is not six o'clock.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What do ye laugh at?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: At you, my dear—why, 'tis past seven—Oh! Belinda, you are the stricken deer, I find—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Who I?—not I truly—I—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: My dear Belinda, you are—and come, we will do the good natured thing by you,—and leave you to yourselves—Success attend you—come, Mr. Bellmont—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Thyrsis, a youth of the inspired train, Fair Sacharissa lov'd, but lov'd in vain.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Po! po! (looking peevishly at her.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What, won't you know me, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, madam, I know you—it is but too true, that I know you—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Prithee, give over these humours—what, still gloomy and discontented!—come, come, under pain of my displeasure, brighten up this moment.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Po! po!—silly, ridiculous, and idle!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Come, come, when I proclaim a pardon, you had better embrace it, than reduce yourself to the necessity of sighing, vowing, protesting, writing to me, following me up and down, kneeling at my feet, imploring forgiveness—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam, I shall never be brought to forgive—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Upon my word! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! you may laugh, ma'am, you have too long imposed upon my fond, easy credulity; but the witchery of your charms is over—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well, Sir! and you are your own man again.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am, madam, and you may be your own woman again, or any body's woman, or every body's—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You grow rude, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It is time to wave all ceremony, and to tell you plainly, that your falshood—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: My falshood, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Your falshood!—I know the whole affair—I loved you once, Belinda, tenderly loved you, and by heaven I swear, it is with sorrow that I can no longer adore you, and that I now bid you an everlasting farewel— (going.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Explain, Sir—what action of my life?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Your prudence forsook you at last—it was too glaring—too manifest in open day—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Too manifest in open day!—Mr. Beverley, I shall hate you—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, all circumstances inform against you—my picture given away—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Insolent! provoking! wrong-headed man! I'll confirm him in his error, to torment him (aside.)—Well, Sir, what if I chose to give it away!—I am mistress of my own actions, am I not?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
