sp.p: Oh! I know that, ma'am—I know that—and I am not uneasy, ma'am—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: So it seems—ha! ha!—why do you sigh, poor man?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sigh, madam!—I disdain it—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I am glad of it; now that is so manly! but pray watch yourself well, hold a guard upon all your passions, otherwise they will make a fool of you again—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And do you take care you don't expose yourself again—lolling familiarly in a gentleman's arms!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Here, in the Park!—in open day!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What can this be?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: He inviting you to his house!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! I understand him now,—when I fainted, all this was—I'll encourage his notion, to be revenged of his waspish temper (aside.)—Well, Sir, and what then?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What then?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
Ha! ha!—poor Mr. Beverley!—why should you be in a piteous taking, because I, in the gaiety of my heart, give away a picture I set no value on, or walk with a gentleman I do
set a value on, or lean on his arm, or make the man happy by letting him draw on my glove—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Or draw off your glove, madam—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ay! or draw it off—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, or—or—or take any other liberties—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very true—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You may make light of it, madam—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Why yes, a generous temper always makes light of the favours it confers—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And some generous tempers will make light of any thing to gratify their inclinations—Madam, I have done—I abjure you—eternally abjure you.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Bon voyage!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Don't think to see me again—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Adieu!—Well, what, coming again—what, lingering— (repeats affectedly)
Thus o'er the dying lamp, the unsteady flame
Hangs quivering to a point—&c.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: With what an air she carries it—I have but this one thing more to tell you—by heaven I loved you—to excess I loved you—such is my weakness, I shall never quite forget you—I shall be glad, if hereafter I hear of your happiness, and, if I can, no dishonour shall fall on you—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—well! my obliging, generous Don Quixote, go and sight windmills, castles in the air, and a thousand phantoms of your own creation, for your Dulcinea's sake, do—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Confusion!—mind, madam—that this is the last time of my troubling you—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I shall expect you to-morrow morning—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No—never—by heaven, never—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Exactly at ten—your usual hour—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: May I perish at your feet, if I do—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! brave—but remember ten—kneeling, beseeching, imploring, your hand upon your heart, "Belinda, won't you forgive me?—"

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Damnation!—I have done—I here bid you an eternal adieu!—farewel—

sp.speaker: BELIN.

div3.head: SCENE, an Apartment in Beverley's House.

sp.p: SO! so! so! Belinda, I have escaped your snares, and have recovered my freedom;—and yet, if she had not proved false, what a treasure of love had I in store for all that beauty!—Po! po! no more of her beauty—it is external, superficial, the mere result of features and complexion—A deceitful Syren, to draw the unwary into a dream of happiness, and then wake him into wonder at the storms and tempests that gather round him.—I have done with her; I'll think no more of her—Oh! Belinda! Belinda!—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Please your honour—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She that in every part of life seemed so amiable!—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Under so fair a mask to wear such loose designs!—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: What is he musing upon?—Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have done with her for ever—ay, for ever— (hums a tune)—I swear for ever— (sings)—are you there, Brush?—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Yes, your honour—here is a letter.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: So unforeseen, so unexpected a discovery!—Well! well! well!—what did you say, Brush?—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: A letter for your honour, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well, give it to me another time—I'll not make myself uneasy about her—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: I fancy your honour will be glad to have it now—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What did you say?

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: It is a letter from madam Belinda, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda! I won't read it—take it away—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Hey! which way is the wind now?—some quarrel, I suppose—but the falling out of lovers—must I take it away, Sir?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have done with her for ever.—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Have done with madam Belinda, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! Brush, she is—but I will not proclaim her shame—no, let me still be tender—I will see her no more, Brush, that is all; hear from her no more; she must not wind herself about my heart again—I'll go out of town directly—order my chaise to the door.

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Had you not better deser it till morrow morning, Sir? perhaps then—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No—no—directly—do as I bid you—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Consider, Sir, if your mind should change, the trouble of coming back post-haste—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No—never—I say, never—what to her? Who could smile on me, on him, on a thousand—no,—no—she shall know that I am a man—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p:
But, Sir, you know that one solitary tear, which, after miserably chasing for it for half an hour together, she will painfully distil from
the corner of her eye, will extinguish all this rage, and then—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Po! po! you know nothing of the matter—go, and order the chaise directly—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—I suppose a couple of shirts will be sufficient, Sir?—you will hardly stay them out—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Pack up all, Sir—I shall stay in the country a whole month, if it be necessary—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: An entire month, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am resolved, fixed, determined,—and so, do as I have ordered you.— (Exit Brush)—So shall I disentangle myself from her entirely—so shall I forget the fondness my foolish heart had for her—I hate her, loath her, pity her, am sorry for her, and love her still—I must expel this weakness from my mind—I will think no more of her—and yet—Brush! Brush!—I may as well see her letter too—only to try what her cunning can suggest.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You may as well leave the letter, Brush—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Yes, Sir;—I thought as much—

sp.speaker: BEVERLEY
sp.p: Now what varnish will she put upon the matter!— (reads)

The false gaiety of my heart, thro' which my dear Beverley might have read my real anguish at our last meeting, is now subsided. If you will come to me, I will not laugh at your inquietude of temper, but will clear all your doubts, and shew you how much I am, my dearest Beverley, ever yours,
BELINDA BLANDFORD.

Pshaw! satisfy my doubts—I have no doubts; I am convinced—these arts prevail no more—ha! ha! (laughs peevishly)—"my dear Beverley" (reads, and tears the letter by degrees)—"real anguish"—ha! ha! (tears another piece)—"inquietude of temper"— (another piece)—"clear all your doubts"—Po! po! po!—ha! ha!—damnation!—I'll think no more of her— (tears another bit)—ha! ha!—"dearest Beverley"—ha! ha!—artful woman!—"ever yours"—false! false! false!— (tears another piece)—I'll not make myself uneasy about her—Perfidy! treachery! and ingratitude!— (fixes his eye, looks uneasy, and tears the letter all in scraps.)

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: So, brother!—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Beverley!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sister, your servant—Mr. Bellmont, yours—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: You seem melancholy, brother.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No, not I—I am in very good spirits—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—my dear brother, that is seen thro', your soul is upon the rack.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What about a woman, a false, ungrateful woman!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Whom you still admire—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: To whom you'll be upon your knees in five minutes.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You are mistaken—I am going out of town—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But you will take your leave—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have done that, once for all.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Has not she wrote to you?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She has; and there,—there you see the effect of her letter.—You will see I shall maintain a proper firmness on the occasion—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Prithee no more, Beverley, but return to your duty—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I beg, Sir, you will have done—what, plead for treachery, for falshood, for deceit—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: No, Sir, but for my friend, my lovely friend, for Belinda, for truth, for innocence—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Po! po! you don't know all the circumstances—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: But we do know all the circumstances, and, my dear brother, you have behaved very ill.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Heaven knows, I have not, and yet, heaven knows, I should be glad to be convinced I have—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: I'll tell you what then, we women are soft and compassionate in our nature; go to her without delay, fall at her feet, beg her pardon, drop a tear or two, and all will be well again.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Prithee don't laugh at me,—may contempt and beggary attend me,—may all the calamities of life befal me,—may shame, confusion, and disquiet of heart for ever sting me,—if I hold farther intercourse with her; if I do not put her from my thoughts for ever.—Did you leave her at home?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: We did.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well, let her slay there—it is of no consequence to me—how did she bear what passed between us?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Like a sweet girl as she is; she behaved like an angel; I shall love her better than ever for her good humour.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! I don't doubt her good humour—she has smiles at command—let her smile or not smile, 'tis all alike to me—did she say any thing?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: She told us the whole story, and told it in tears too.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Ay! them she can command too!—But I have no curiosity about her—was she in tears tho'?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: She was, and wept bitterly—how could you, brother, behave so rashly to so amiable a girl?—have you a pleasure in being the cause of her uneasiness?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I the cause!—you wrong me—by heaven you wrong me—my lady Restless was the cause—she told me such things—she planted daggers in my very heart.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: You planted daggers in her heart—and it was barbarous.—What, because a lady has not strength enough to bear up against a father, who is resolved to give her away to another, and because she faints out of excessive tenderness for you, and in that distress meets accidental relief from Sir John Restless at his own door—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: How!—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: And because my lady Restless sees this out of her window, and has a perverse talent of misinterpreting appearances into realities, to her own disadvantage—you must therefore fill your head with ungenerous suspicions—Oh! for shame, for shame, how could you?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But, is all this true?—is this really the case?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How can you doubt it, Beverley;—you know Belinda too well—it is the case, man.—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I should be glad to find it so—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p:
Well! well! I tell you it is so—how could you think otherwise, when you know she has the best heart in the world, and is so nice of
honour, she scorns all falshood and dissimulation—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! my dear Beverley, you have done the absurdest thing—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Why, if what you say can be made to appear—but then she'll never forgive my past behaviour—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Po! you talk as if you were wholly unletter'd in the tempers of women—my dear brother, you know, you men can do what you please with us, when you have got an interest in our hearts—go to her, I say, go to her, and make your peace—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: May I depend upon what you say?—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Then I'll fly to her this instant, humble myself to her, and promise by all my future life to attone for this brutal injury—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: The chaise is at the door, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You may put up again; I shan't go out of town.

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: No, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: No—ha! ha!—you may put up, and let me have the chariot directly—

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I knew it would come to this—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But do you think she will forgive me?

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: She will; love will plead your cause.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
My dear sister, I am for ever obliged to you;—and Bellmont, I thank you too—how could I wrong her so?—I shall behold her once again—ha! ha!—is the chariot ready?—I won't stay for it; I am on the wing, my dear Belinda, to implore forgiveness—and so she fainted away
in the Park, and my lady Restless saw Sir John afford her relief?—ha! ha! ha!—whimsical enough—ha! ha! ha!—what a strange construction her crazy temper put upon it?—ha! ha!—how could the woman be so foolish?—my dear Belinda, I will fly to you this moment—ha! ha!— (going, returns) Sir John shall give me back the picture, and, on my knees, I will once more present it—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: So! so! so!—you are come to yourself, I find—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I knew it would be so—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: She shall have it—I'll find Sir John directly—and then—ha! ha! how could I be such a madman! ha! ha!—sister, your servant—Bellmont, yours—ha! ha! what a piece of work has that foolish woman made for us all—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Well, I am happy that I have nothing of my brother's unaccountable humours in my disposition—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! my angel, you are all—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh lord! Oh lord!—no compliments, pray—I have not leisure now to attend to you—for, positively, I must go back to Belinda, to see their reconciliation—will you go with me, Mr. Bellmont?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: By all means—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Allons then; there, take my hand, and let us be gone.

This rash, unaccountable man!—How could he entertain such a suspicion!—Ungratesul Beverley!—He
almost deserves I should never see him again.—Tippet!—I shan't be easy till I hear from him—Tippet!—

sp.speaker: BELIND.
sp.p: Is the servant returned from Mr. Beverley's?—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Not yet, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I wonder what keeps him.—I am upon thorns till I see the dear, ungenerous man, and explain every thing to him—Oh! Mr. Beverley! how could you treat me so?—But I was partly to blame; my lady Restless inflamed his mind, and I should not have trisled with his passion—Is the other servant returned from Sir John Restless?—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: He is, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: And what answer?—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Sir John will wait upon you himself, madam, directly.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well!—I must get him to set every thing in its true light, and justify me to Mr. Beverley: and yet the uncertainty of his temper alarms me strangely—his eternal suspicions!—but there is nothing in that—my future conduct,—my regard for him will cure that disease, and then—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I dare be sworn it will, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Yes, I think it will; when he knows me better, he will learn to think generously of me—and on my part, I think I can be sure he will meet with nothing but open, unsuspecting love from me.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: Sir John Restless, madam—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Shew him in—Tippet, do you leave the room.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: In compliance with your commands, Madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, I am much obliged to you for the trouble you have been pleased to give yourself—A particular circumstance has happened in your family, to my utter disquiet—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Madam, there have happened things in my family, to my utter disquiet too—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I am sorry for that, Sir—but I assure you I have been made quite unhappy, and must beg, as it is in your power, that you will be kind enough to remove the cause of my uneasiness.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Whatever I can do, you may command.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you, and must tell you, that your lady has done me the most irreparable injury.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! she has done the same to me—my injuries are irreparable too—but how has she injured you, madam?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: She has ruined me, Sir, with the man I love to distraction.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now, here something else will come to light, (aside.)—How, how has she done that, madam?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, she has entirely drawn off his affections from me.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And fixed them upon herself, I suppose.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I don't say that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: But I dare say it; and I believe it.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, I don't charge the lady with any thing of that kind—but she has unaccountably taken it into her head to be jealous of me.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Jealous of you!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Her ladyship saw the little offices of civility I received from you this morning—She misunderstood every thing, it seems, and has told the gentleman with whom I was engaged in a treaty of marriage, that improper freedoms have passed between us.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Artifice! artifice!—her usual policy, madam, to cover her own libertine ways.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I don't mean to say any thing harsh of the lady—but you know what foundation there is for this, and I hope will do me justice—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! madam, to the world, to the wide world I'll justify you—I will wait upon the gentleman—who is he, madam?—what's his name?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Beverley, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Beverley!

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; you seem surprised—do you know him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know him—and he shall know me—my resentment he shall feel—he shall answer to me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Answer to you!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: To me, madam—I told you at first this was her scheme to shelter herself; and he, I suppose, is combined with her to give this turn to the affair, and to charge me with infidelity—But you, ma'am, can witness for me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I can, Sir—But can Mr. Beverley be capable of a dishonourable action?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! that matter is plain enough; he has injured me in the highest degree, destroyed my happiness—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: How, Sir!—are you sure of this?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He has giver her his picture; I caught her with her eyes rivetted to it; I heard her admiration, her praises of it; her wishes that she had been married to such a man—I saw her print a thousand kisses on it; and in the very fact I wrested it out of her hand—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I assure you, Sir, if I imagined him to be such as you describe him, I should scarcely be willing to join myself to him for life—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: As you please for that—but, without doubt, you must be very happy with a man of his gallantry.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Happy, Sir!—I should be miserable; I should be distracted—I should break my heart—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! it is very likely that he will have a great regard to the honour of the nuptial bed, he, who is so ready to commit a trespass on his neighbour.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But do you think you have sufficient proof?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I have seen him coming out of my house since, clandestinely, shunning every observant eye, with the characters of guilt in his face, and all the discourse I had with him, served only to convince me the more—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Abandoned wretch!—was this the love he professed for me?—Sir, I have only to hope that you will vindicate me in this matter—I commend myself to your honour, and I thank you for this favour—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Our evidences will mutually speak
for each other, and confound their dark designs—Madam, I take my leave—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, your most obedient—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You will find I shall make an example of the gentleman—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You cannot treat him too severely—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I will expose him, I promise you—Madam, your humble servant.

sp.speaker: BELINDA.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Beverley, could I have imagined this?—False! false man!—and yet how shall I forget him!—But I will make an effort, tho' it pierce me to the quick—I will tear him from my heart—this moment I will write to him, and forbid him to see me more.

If I can procure sufficient evidence, I shall bring the matter to a divorce, and make an example of them all—Would Marmalet were come—this is her time to a moment—If I can worm the secret out of her—then I am happy—Is not that she yonder?—there is not quite day-light enough to distinguish, but I think I perceive a person masked—hist! hist!—Mrs. Marmalet—she comes this way—it is she—Mrs. Marmalet, your servant—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You are very good, Mrs. Marmalet—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Bless my heart, I am seared out of my senses.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What's the matter, pray?—what's the matter?

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Oh Sir! I tremble like a leaf—I was accosted in a rude manner by some gentlemen yonder—Oh Lord! I can't stay here, let us go into your house, Sir—I beg you will.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My house—would not any other house do as well?

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir—not for the world—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Why my wife is not at home, and so I think I may venture, not but I had rather it were elsewhere—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir John, I can't—you will do me a favour if you will take me into the house—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Very well—say no more—it shall be so—Robert—

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Is that Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Your lady is not at home, Robert, is she?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Then do you go in, and take care that nobody sees Mrs. Marmalet with me—come, I'll shew you the way—

div3.head: SCENE in Sir JOHN's House.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Ay, poor lady! she is misfortunate, indeed—and, poor gentleman, he is as jealous as my lady to the full—There has been a deal to do about that picture you mention, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well, all that will be explained presently—I'll wait till he comes home—I can't possibly go without speaking to him—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Indeed, you had better not stay, Sir—you don't consider the mischief your being in the house may occasion—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Mischief! how do ye mean?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Lord, Sir!—I would not have you stay for the world—I would not, indeed—you can call again in an hour, Sir, and you'll certainly find him at home, then—Bless my heart, Sir!—I fancy that's his voice—do, dear Sir!—you'll be the ruin of my lady—If he sees you here, Sir, waiting in his house—he'll be persuaded you come after my lady—the world will never beat it out of his head—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: But I shall give him to understand—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: He won't understand any thing, Oh lud! oh lud! he's coming up—I'll run and look.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What a flurry the woman is in—a foolish jade!—I must speak with him now—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: (Entering.) It is he as I am alive, Sir—and there is a woman in a mask with him—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: A woman in a mask—Zoons, if that should be Belinda!—my mind misgives me strangely!—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Do, dear Sir—you look like a goodnatured gentleman—Let me hide you out of the way, Sir,—you would not be the destruction of a poor servant—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: A mask coming home with him—I must know who that is—I won't leave the house without knowing—If I could conceal myself—Have you any private place, Mrs. Tattle?—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: That is the very thing I mean, Sir—Let me conceal you in that closet till he passes thro' this room—He never stays long here—it won't take you two minutes—Do, sweet Sir—I'll down on my knees to you—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
That will be the best way—Come, dispose
of me as you will—If this should be Belinda—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Heavens bless you, Sir, for this goodness!—I'll lock the door to make sure work of it—Oh lud! Oh lud! I was never so frightened in my life—

div3.stage: Enter Sir JOHN, and a Woman masked.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Mrs. Marmalet, I am obliged to you for this favour—I wanted a word or two with you—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: So Robert informed me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Did he tell you my business?

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: No, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Look ye then, my dear Mrs. Marmalet, if you will gratify me in what I shall ask, you may command any thing—now you may be uncovered—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: La! Sir—I hear a noise—I am afraid somebody's coming—and I shall be seen.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Hush! no—there's nobody—I'll tell you what—If you will indulge me on this occasion, I am yours for ever—Here, here is a purse of money for you—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: But if this should come to the knowledge of your lady, I am ruined and undone—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, I'll take care of you—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: Will you, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I will—but come—let me remove this from your face—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: But somebody may come—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I'll lock the door—there, now we are sate—

sp.speaker: MASK.
sp.p: But in a little time you'll make up all quarrels with your lady, and I shall get ruined by this—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, never fear—I shall never be reconciled to her—I hate her—detest her—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Do you so, Sir?—Now, Sir John, what can you say now, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My Lady Restless!—Confusion!—What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh, Sir John! Sir John!—what evasion have you now, Sir?—Can you deny your guilt any longer?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This is unlucky—that villain Robert has betrayed me—and I can't explain myself to her now—try what soothing will do—My Lady Restless—if you will but have patience all this matter shall be explained—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Explained, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, explained, and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: My dear, too!—the assurance of you!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I say, my dear, for I still regard you—and this was all done—to—to—cure you of your jealousy—all done to cure you of your jealousy.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: A fine way you have taken—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, yes—and so you will see presently—all to convince you how groundless your suspicions are; and then we shall live very happy together—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Ay!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: For I have no further suspicions of you—I see my error, and I want you to see yours—ha! ha!—I have no suspicions—that will put her her off her guard— (aside)—my dear, only compose your spirits, and—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And do you think to deny every thing even in the face of conviction—Base, base man!—I'll go this moment and write to my brother—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Po! po! you talk wildly—this is all raving—you make yourself very ridiculous—you do, indeed—I had settled all this on purpose, and contrived that it should come to your ears, and then knew you would do just as you have done—and—then—I—I—resolved to do just as I have dare—only to hint to you—that listeners seldom hear any good of themselves, and so shew you how wrong it is to be too suspicious, my dear—and was it not well done?—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: And do you laugh at me too, Sir?—make me your sport?—I'll go and get pen and ink this moment—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! do so, ma'am—do so—ha! ha! you'll only expose yourself—go and write, madam—ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I will, Sir—ha! the door is locked—this won't succeed, Sir—I suppose you have the key—ay! I'll lay my life you have, and some other of your creatures is locked in there—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: There, again—this is of a piece with all your other suspicions—ha! ha!—you are mighty silly, indeed, you are—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I will search that closet—I am determined I will—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Do so, ma'am, do so—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I'll have the door broke open, if you don't give me the key—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Will you give me the key, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—Tattle!—who waits there?—I will find out all your artifices—Tattle, I say—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Tol de rol lol—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of the key of that closet, Tattle?

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: The key, ma'am!—I have it, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Give it to me—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: That is, I have it not, ma'am—oh! Crimini—what shall I do now?—don't have it, ma'am, don't ask for it?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Don't ask for it!—but I will have it, and so—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ha! is not she willing to give it?—there is something in this, then—Give the key this moment, you jade, give it to me—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You shan't have it, Sir—what, you want to hinder me!—give the key to me—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Lord! I have lost it, ma'am—better not have it, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Give it to me this moment, I say.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: If you don't let me have it, it is as much as your place is worth—

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: The devil is in it—there it is then—let me make my escape.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Now, Sir, we shall see—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay, now search, if you will—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You shall be found out, I promise you—oh! (screams out)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Heavens! who have we here?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh there is somebody there then!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam—your most obedient—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: By all that's false, here he is again!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: What, in the name of wonder, brings you here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh madam! you know his business—and I know his business—and the gentleman knows his business—There he is, ma'am!—there is the gentleman waiting for you—true to his appointment, you see—Sir, your humble servant—my lady Restless, your very humble servant, madam.—Now write to your brother—do—I should be glad to know what you can say now—now—now—is the case plain now?—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I am in amaze! I don't know what to make of this.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, however odd this may appear—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! now settle it between yourselves—give it what turn you will, Sir, she will confirm it,—you need not be afraid, Sir—you will agree in your story—she is quick of invention, I assure you,—and I dare say you are pretty quick too!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I must beg you will put no forced construction upon this matter—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And you beg the same, ma'am, don't you?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I beg to be heard—my business here, Sir, is to desire you will return me that picture you have in your possession!—it is now become dear to me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I dare say it is—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And I must have it back.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, it is of equal value to me, and it shall rise in evidence against you both.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Evidence against me!—pray Sir, I desire you will explain yourself.—How did you get in here?—what's your business?—what brought you hither?—what's your errand?—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, speak; how did you get in here?—what's your business?—what brought you hither?—what's your errand?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Zoons! I am beset by them both at once—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Speak, Sir,—explain—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! Sir, explain—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, if you will give me leave, I will satisfy you entirely—I assure you, Sir, and you too, ma'am, that my being in your closet is entirely owing to your maid, Tattle—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The jade, I don't doubt it, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: To prevent, if possible, the interpretation you now put upon seeing me in your house—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And it was well contrived, Sir—Oh! my lady Restless—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: By all that's just, I knew nothing of it—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Nothing, upon my honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! I knew you would both agree—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman, I tell you the real fact.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You need not, Sir, I know the real fact.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I have no time to lose, and I must now desire the picture, directly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, I wish you a good evening.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I can't stir without it; and I should be glad you would comply without a quarrel, or really I must be obliged to—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay! now her bully begins! (aside.)—I desire you will quit my house, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I am not to be treated in this manner, Sir, and, if you don't return it by fair means, I shall be forced to draw, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: There again now!—she has set him on to cut my throat—but I will disappoint her—she is a worthless woman, and I won't fight about her.—There, Sir, there is your trinket—I shall have proof sufficient without it—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Upon my honour, Sir, you will have no proof of any misbehaviour of mine, and, if you suspect your lady from these appearances, you wrong her much, I assure you—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir, I desire you will explain all this—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Call up your maid, madam, and—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, Sir, no more of it—I am satisfied—I wish you good night, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, when you are willing to listen to reason, I shall at any time convince you how wrong you are, and madam, you may depend I shall do justice to your honour upon all occasions—and I take my leave—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now, my lady Restless, now you see you are thoroughly known; all your artifices are known—Mr. Beverley is known! my lord Conquest is known—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: My lord Conquest, Sir! I despise all your imputations—my lord Conquest's maid, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Very well, madam! 'tis now my turn to write to your brother, and I promise you I will do it—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: You will write, Sir!—you will write!—I will recollect my temper—his assurance is unequalled (aside.)—Oh! do so, Sir,—do so—ha! ha! but you will only expose your weakness—ha! ha! you make yourself very ridiculous! you do indeed!—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! madam, am I to be insulted with a contumelious laugh into the bargain!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Why, my dear, this was all done—to—to—to—cure you of your jealousy—for I knew you would do as you have done, and so I—resolved to do as I have done—was it not well done, my dear, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Damnation, madam!—this is beyond all human patience—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! la lall lall lall, (sings and laughs)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Let me tell you, it is no laughing matter—you are a vile woman; I know you, and the world shall know you—I promise you it shall—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I am clear in my own conviction, and your slander I despise—nor shall your artifice blind me or my friends any longer—Sir, as you say it is no laughing matter—and I promise you, Sir—you shall never dishonour me again in this house—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And I promise you, madam, that you shall never dishonour me in any house.—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Injurious, false, false man!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Deceitful—wanton—wanton woman!—

div3.stage: Enter old BLANDFORD, Sir WILLIAM, and young BELLMONT.

sp.speaker: BLANDFORD.
sp.p: WELL, Sir William, we have made a good day's work of it, the writings will be ready to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: The sooner the better, is your daughter Belinda at home?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: I dare say she is—I ordered her home in the morning, I make no doubt but she has been at home ever since—I'll call her to you—excuse me a moment, Sir William,—young gentleman, I beg your pardon—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No ceremony, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: I suppose you was coming hither, George, to wait upon your mistress, when I met you but now—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir—you may depend—every thing in my power to please you, Sir—but you know I told you already, Sir, that the lady has declared an aversion for me.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p:
An aversion!—a fiddle for her aversion—has not her father promised her to you in
marriage?—and so, what have you to do with her aversion?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: To do with it, Sir!—egad, I am afraid I shall have a great deal to do with it,—you know, when a young lady marries against her inclination, billets-doux, assignations, plots, and intrigues, and a terrible et caetera of female stratagems, mount into her brain, and—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Come, come, lad, don't play the rogue with your father—did not you promise me, if Belinda consented, the affair would meet with no obstacle from you?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I did, Sir,—but I can't help thinking—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: And I can't help thinking that you are a knave, George.—I'll tell you what, I have fixed my heart upon this marriage—my friend Mr. Blandford and I have been dining upon parchment, as I may say; we have been at the Crown and Rolls all day, to read over the deeds—and so I tell you, once for all, you must be observant of my will and pleasure.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir, if Belinda—she will never consent (aside.)—If the lady, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Very well, she will be consenting—I warrant her—now we shall see—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Ods heart! I am overjoyed, Sir William—my daughter is a complying, good girl, and obedient to her father—young gentleman, I give you joy.—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Death to my hopes! what does he mean?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Sir William, give me your hand upon it—this will not only be a match of prudence, but inclination also—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: There, George, there's news for you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sure she won't bring this calamity on me—Can I believe what I hear, madam?—will you yourself pronounce the sentence?—

sp.speaker: BELin.
sp.p: Sir, I must take shame to myself, that I have been so long refractory to the dictates of the best of fathers, and blind also to your merit.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Confusion! (aside)—My merit, I am afraid, is over-rated by you, and—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir;—I must freely declare that my heart has been fixed upon a worthless man, whom I now renounce, and to you, Sir, I am ready to resign myself.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: There, there, all's fixed, and my blessing attend you both.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What a dilemma am I brought into here?

sp.speaker: Sir WIL
sp.p: George, what's the matter, boy?—you a bridegroom!—wounds! at your age I would cut a caper over the moon on such an occasion.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir, I must beg to be excused—I am a little more slack-mettled, Sir, and can't leap quite so high.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Well, well, all in good time—Mr. Blandford, where is this bottle you promised me?—I want to wash down the cobwebs of the law—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: In truth so do I—Who waits there?—Richard, lay a table in the next room—come, come, we'll go and drink a bumper to the young couple.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: With all my heart—George, you are a cup too low; come with us my lad, we'll cheer your spirits—come along, George (going.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I attend you, Sir—is this true, Belinda?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: My real sentiments, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Then you have undone us all.

sp.speaker: BELINDA.
sp.p: Yes, I am resolved at length, and I will punish his falsehood and ingratitude by obeying my father's commands. But my friend, Clarissa, has she deserved this of me?—My resentments have hurried me too far—Resume your strength, my heart, and let no sudden gust of passion make you false to friendship and to honour—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, Tippet, have you done as I ordered you?

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I have, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: A vile, persidious man!

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: So he is, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: After all the love I professed for him!—after so many ardent vows and protestations as he has made me—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: After the hours he has kneel'd at your feet!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I will drive him from my thoughts—here, take this letter, Tippet—give it to him with your own hands.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Where are his letters?

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Here, madam. (shews a parcel)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: The bracelet—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I have it safe.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Mighty well—take them all home to him,—and, in return, bring me back my foolish letters to him.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Madam, I won't quit the house without them.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: That letter will inform him that his Falsehood has compelled me into a compliance with my father's intentions, and be sure you confirm that to him.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: He shall hear it of every side of his ears, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well, you may go—and, hark ye, Tippet—ask his man,—as if from yourself,—carelesly,—whether his master ever talked of me—and what he said, Tippet?—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: But I don't care what he said—I don't want to know any thing about him—it does not concern me now—no—no—let him care as little for me as I do for him—Tell him I say so—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I shan't forget, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Tell him to hate me as much as I do him.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I'll tell him his own—I promise you, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well—that's all;—get you gone—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Mind what I have said—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Trust to me—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Don't forget a tittle—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: No, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Be sure you tell him how indifferent I am—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Leave all to me.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You see, Tippet, I am quite unconcerned—the barbarous wretch!

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Oh! yes, ma'am, I see—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: It is easy to see that I am not all uneasy—You see that I am very gay upon it— (laughs affectedly.)

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: (Laughs) Yes, ma'am—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: False! false Beverley!—Tell him I will never see his face any more.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I am gone, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: That upon no account will I ever exchange a word with him, hear from him, of him, or have any thing of any kind whatever to do with him—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: I have my lesson, ma'am.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Mr. Beverley, madam.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: My lady won't see his face any more.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Yes, I think, I will—shew him in—I will see him once more, and tell him all myself—You may withdraw, Tippet.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am—ah! she has a hankerafter him still.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Now will I upbraid him, now tell him his own, and—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda!—how gladly do I once again behold—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: And with what resentment have not I reason to behold, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You have, Belinda;—you have reason, I grant it—but—forgive the rash words my folly uttered—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, mistake me not—they are not your words I quarrel with;—your actions, Mr. Beverley, your actions, Sir!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: They are not to be extenuated—but surely, after the letter you honoured me with—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, I have heard every thing since I was guilty of that folly.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Heard! what?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Yes, dissemble if you will—but this must be the last of our conversing—My maid will return you whatever I have received from you;—and all my silly letters I must beg you will let me have,—and then visit me no more, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda!—you will not wound me thus—Here is the picture which caused that unlucky mistake between us—I have recovered it from Sir John Restless—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: From my Lady Restless, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Madam!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! fie, Sir—no more—I have done—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: You must, you must accept it—Thus on my knees I beg you will—Will you, Belinda?—(takes her hand.)

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Leave me, Sir—let go my hand, Mr. Beverley—your falshood, Sir—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: My falshood!—by all the—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Your falshood, Sir—Sir John Restless has told me all—every circumstance—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: He has told you!—What has he told? his life shall answer it—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: How could you treat me thus?—you have destroyed my peace of mind for ever—Nay, you yourself have forced me into the arms of another—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: What do I hear?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: In obedience to the commands of a father, I have agreed to marry Mr. Bellmont.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Mr. Bellmont!—him!—marry him!—it is very well, ma'am,—I expected it would come to this—and my Lady Restless is only mentioned on this occasion, as a retort for my accusation about Sir John—I understand it—and, by heaven! I believe that whole story—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: You do, Sir!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I do—Fool that I was to humble myself to you—My pride is now piqued, and I am glad, ma'am—as glad as you can be to break off for ever—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, I can be as indifferent on my part—Then, Sir, you have only to send me back my letters, and—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! agreed, agreed—I'll go home this moment, and send them all—and before I go, ma'am, here is your own picture, which you had given me with your own hands.—Mr. Bellmont will be glad of it—or Sir John Restless will be glad of it—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very like, Sir,—(takes the picture) Tyrant, tyrant man! to treat me in this barbarous manner—(cries.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Tears! Belinda! (approaching)—Belinda!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: No more of your insidious arts—I will hear no more—Oh! my heart,—my heart will break—I did not think it was in your nature to behave as you have done; but—farewel for ever—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p:
Belinda!—hear me but speak—By heaven, my Lady Restless—She is gone—'sdeath! I have been duped by her all this time; I
will now summon up all that is man within me, and in my turn despise her.

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: If you are going home, Sir, I will take the things with me now—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Yes, I am going—I will leave this detested—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: This abominable place, Sir— (laughing at him.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: This hell!—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—ay! Sir, this hell—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: This mansion of perfidy, ingratitude, and fraud—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Very right, Sir, let us go—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And yet—Tippet,—you must not stir—indulge me but a little—it is all a misunderstanding, this—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: My lady will have no more to say to these things—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! Tippet, use your interest with her—keep them in the house till I return—I will clear up this whole matter presently—I must not lose her thus—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Poor gentleman! he seems in a lamentable way—Well, I fancy for my part he is a true lover after all; that's what I do—and my young lady, I fear, is—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Madam, madam, madam, you are to blame—you are, indeed—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: He is, madam.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Did he say any thing? was he uneasy?—or did he carry it off with a—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, he went away sighing short, his heart throbbing, his eyes brimful, his looks pale—you are to blame, you are, indeed, madam—I dare be sworn he has never proved false.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! Tippet, could I be sure of that—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: But you are not sure of the contrary—Why won't you see my Lady Restless?—see her directly, madam; go to her now before it is too late;—before the old folks, who are now putting their heads together, have settled the whole affair—do, dear ma'am, be advised—shall I order your chair?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I don't know what to say—I am afraid I love him still—yes, I will see my Lady Restless—I will be thoroughly informed of the whole matter—order my chair—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am; I will, ma'am.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: If I should lose him thro' a misapprehension of things, I shall never be able to forgive myself; and if rightly informed, the world combined shall not induce me to look upon him again.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Belinda, you have puzzled matters strangely; you have involved your friend Clarissa, yourself, me, and every body, in the most insurmountable difficulties—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Sir, the provocation I have had from Mr. Beverley—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
You wrong him, I am persuaded you do; and so you will find in the end—But what
can be done now?—the old people are fixed in their resolution, and fixed by your own rashness.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: What can I say, Mr. Bellmont?—the agitation of my mind is such, between hope and doubt, and fear and resentment, that I know not which way to turn myself. If Beverley is false,—if he is true,—I am equally undone.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: So, Mr. Bellmont! (angrily.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! Clarissa, there have been such doings between your brother and me—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: So I find, ma'am—I met him as I came hither—You have had fine doings, indeed—I have heard it all—and you can be false to your promises, ma'am, false to your friends—and you too, Mr. Bellmont, you can be false to all your engagements, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Do me not that injustice, Clarissa—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, don't imagine I am angry with you, or with you, madam—you will be well paired—I give ye both joy—I am heartily glad, Sir, that I at length know you,—I resign him to you, ma'am,—I assure you I do—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Give me but a moment's leave—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Upon my word, Clarissa—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: And upon my word, ma'am—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Nay, but moderate your anger—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Anger! anger, indeed!—I should be sorry any thing that has happened were of consequence enough to disturb my peace of mind—Anger!—no, ma'am, I assure you—Mr. Bellmont, I dare say, will be fully deserving of you; and you, madam, on your part, will very amply deserve such a husband—Anger, indeed!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: If you will but hear me a moment—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: My dear Clarissa—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh! my dear ma'am, you are a sincere friend I know, ma'am (with a sneer) but, my dear ma'am, don't stand on ceremony—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Whatever has passed, Clarissa, I am not to blame—I have ever been—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: You have been false, Sir—but you have my consent, I promise you—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But you won't hear me,—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: No, she won't listen to a word—I mean you no wrong, Clarissa—

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Madam, the chair is ready—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Very well!—I won't lose a moment now—Clarissa, when I return, you will be better disposed to hear me.

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, there is no occasion.—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well! well!—suspend your judgment till I come back; your servant—adieu.—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh! your servant, ma'am—Mr. Bellmont, my brother, I promise you, will never forgive this injury—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: If you will have but a moment's patience—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! I shan't want patience,—don't imagine that—I shall be very patient, I promise you—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Nay, but this is very ill-tempered—one would imagine my lady Restless had been speaking to you too—this is like the rest of them;—downright jealousy—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: Jealousy!—upon my word, Sir, you are of great consequence to yourself, but of none to me I assure you, Sir,—jealousy! I shall die with laughing at the thought—but, before I go, I will write a line to Belinda—to tell her all I know and think of her—Mrs. Tippet will let me have pen, ink, and paper, above stairs—and as to you, Sir—I have told you my mind already—Jealousy!—I can't help being diverted with the very notion of it—your most obedient, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What a deal of mischief has a strange misunderstanding of circumstances occasioned this day!—here comes my father—now to perplex matters if I can—and so gain at least a little delay—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Well, George! every thing is settled—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But still, Sir, I wish you would consider—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: What, at your tricks again, lad?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You know, Sir, I am above even an attempt to deceive you—but only reflect, Sir,—this is but a forced consent from the lady—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: What, going back from your word, George?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Not in the least, Sir; but I am sure, if all circumstances were known to you, you yourself would forbid the banns.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: How! how!—what's the matter, George?—I forbid the banns! for what?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, I am not fond of speaking detractingly of a young lady; but, for the honour
of your family, Sir, let us desist from this match; that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Roguery, lad!—there's roguery in this.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I see you will force me to speak out—there is a flaw in her reputation, Sir; she is blemished—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Blemished!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, blemished; my lady Restless, a very agreeable, worthy lady here in the neighbourhood, has discovered an illicit commerce between her and Sir John—the whole charge is come to Beverley's knowledge, and, with tears in his eyes, with a bleeding heart, for he loved her tenderly, he has made his bow to her charms, and taken his final leave.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Ay! lad—is this true?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Too true, I assure you, Sir—my lady will confirm it;—and so now judge whether—Oh! here comes Mr. Blandford—take no notice to him, Sir;—we need not be accessary to her ruin; it is a family affair, and so let them patch it up among themselves, as well as they can—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: If things be as you say, George—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Supper will be ready immediately, Sir William—odds heart!—my spirits are above proof with joy, that this matter is so happily settled; I am in love with my daughter for her compliance, and I fancy I shall throw in an odd thousand more, to be spent in the honey-moon—Where is Belinda?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I really can't say, Sir; she is not at home.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Not at home!—What can be the meaning of that? where could she go at this hour of night?—I am alarmed—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: She is not gone after this Beverley, I hope!—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: If she is—Tippet!—who answers there?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Where is Belinda?

sp.speaker: TIP.
sp.p: Gone in a chair to Sir John Restless—not far off, Sir; just bye here—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Gone to Sir John Restless!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You see, Sir!—(to Sir William.)

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: I did not think she had been acquainted there—she has got some freak in her head, I fear.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Why, it has an odd appearance this—let us follow her thither—this should be enquired into.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Ay! let us lose no time—let us follow her immediately; come along—

sp.speaker: Sir. WIL.
sp.p: I attend you, Sir—come along, George—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I will but get my hat, in the next room, Sir, and follow you directly.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Very well! now I shall see whether you have imposed upon your father—

And now, Clarissa, now will I explain to you all my sufferings; the very sentiments of my
heart—if my lady Restless persists in her accusation, who knows what turn this affair may still take—I will but speak to Clarissa, and follow them instantly.

head.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment at Sir JOHN's.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: This way, Sir, I will let Sir John know.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I shan't detain him long, you may say.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I thought I heard Sir John talking with my maid.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: The business is pressing, or I should not trouble him at this hour.

sp.speaker: TAT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Did not I hear a man in discourse with my wife!—so—so—so—he has got into my house again!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Well! only say that my business is very urgent, that's all—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I dare say it is—and there she comes to you.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Well, Sir, have you heard any thing farther?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir John has been with Belinda since I had the pleasure of seeing you, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I make no doubt of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And I am informed, that he has taken it into his head to suspect me, madam, which is so very unjust, that—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: (Entering) Yes, Sir, I do suspect you,—and, Sir, this frequent haunting of my house—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir John Restless, you have injured me in my love, in my honour, Sir, and—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, you have injured me in my love and in my honour, Sir—no—not my love, for that is over—I despise her, scorn her, reject her—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: That is ever the way with those who have deserved contempt themselves, Sir John.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, I must beg to discuss this affair with some temperance, for it is of moment to me, and—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: (Running to meet her) There, madam, there you find them both together,— (Pointing at Beverley and lady Restless.)

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Now, Sir; you see she comes to my very house after him, (pointing at Sir John and Belinda.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Now, madam, judge for yourself, (to Belinda.)

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Does this convince you, Sir, (to Beverley)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Mr. Beverley! Both staring at each other.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda! Both staring at each other.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: By heaven! I fear my information is right.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Did you find them together, Sir, (to Sir John.)

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Found them together, madam!—

sp.speaker: BEL
sp.p: Then I am satisfied— Each speaking apart.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Oh! the base man! Each speaking apart.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Abandoned woman! Each speaking apart.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Treacherous Belinda! Each speaking apart.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. BLANDFORD, and Sir WILLIAM.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Sir John Restless,—my lady Restless,—I apprehend you are the gentleman, Sir,—and you the lady, ma'am—I came hither in quest of my daughter—so, Belinda!—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Are you her father?

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: I am, madam,—Mr. Beverley here too!—I see how this is, Belinda—you have eloped from your father, have you?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Eloped! mind that Sir John,—the thing is clear.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: So I think it is—and I should be glad to know which of you encourages her to take this step.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: All Sir John's doings, Sir.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Sir John, I must tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, let me assure you first, there is no such thing.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Heavens deliver me!—how can you say so?—Sir, (to Blandford) I am very sorry to say any thing disagreeable to a father of his daughter—but, when my happiness is destroyed, ceremony is unnecessary,—your daughter has made me miserable, Sir.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: What? how?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir John Restless and she, Sir—I cannot speak, (cries.)

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Belinda! you will make your father wretched—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I make you wretched, Sir!—there is no action of my life—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Sir John Restless—this is my son, Sir—he is interested in this matter.—George, things turn out as you told me,— (aside to him.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am sorry for it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Mr. Blandford, you are father to this lady, Sir—don't make yourself uneasy; for I will vouch for her innocence of my lady's charge against her.

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: He will deny every thing, no doubt—but facts are too stubborn, and ocular demonstration I have had.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Ocular demonstration!

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I have seen their familiarities.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: George, take Clarissa as soon as you will—Mr. Blandford, you will excuse me, if I decline any further treaty with you—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Stay but a little till we hear the whole—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Sir, I desire to hear no more—I am satisfied, and must desire not to marry my son into your family—Clarissa—you have my consent as soon as you please—my son is at your service—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p:
Then, Sir William, since you provoke me, Sir, you shan't have my daughter.
—Mr. Beverley, I no longer oppose your inclinations, she is yours—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Do you slight my son, Sir?—you use me very ill—and I would have you know—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: You shall never refuse my daughter again, I promise you—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Nor shall you my son, Sir—Here, George, take your Clarissa—I give her away to you—

sp.speaker: CLA.
sp.p: The gentleman has declared himself for that lady, and—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, ma'am, that lady has no share in my affections, and, in compliance with my father's injunctions, thus let me seize your hand, and devote to you all my future days.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: It's very well, Sir William,—Mr. Beverley, here is my daughter for you—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Ay, now, if he will accept of her, I shall begin to think that I have been mistaken—and that all my suspicions of the lady are without foundation—But, I dare say, the gentleman knows better—What do you say, Sir? will you marry the lady?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: If that proof will satisfy you, madam—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Hold, hold, a moment—Explain the business that brought you hither, Sir; answer to Sir John's charge against you—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN
sp.p: Ay, Sir, answer that—if she agrees to marry him, I shall be satisfied too—But, Sir, my lady's being in possession of your picture, your frequent visits to my house, Sir, and other circumstances—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Sir, a word or two will clear that matter—I had given a picture to this lady in the Park—she, I find, dropped it when she fainted away—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Did you faint, Belinda?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I did, Sir, immediately after you treated me in such severe terms—in the morning—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And then it was I accidentally came to her relief, which my lady, according to custom, has conceived in the manner you see.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: And how came you by the picture, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I found it in the very spot where I saw your daughter in the Park. The truth begins to break in upon me—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This opens my eyes a little—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: And have you been ingenious enough, madam, to work up all these circumstances into a charge against Sir John—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: 'I is ever her way, Sir—I told you how ridiculous you would make yourself, my dear; ha! ha!—You see, what your suspicions are come to at last—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: And you may see, Sir John, what your suspicions are come to—I never was within your doors before this day; nor should I perhaps have spoke to my lady, had it not been for the mistakes your mutual jealousies occasioned between Belinda and me—I cannot help laughing at the whole affair—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, you may laugh—but I have another complaint against my Lady Restless—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir John, Sir John, I have another charge against you—that jade whom you made an assignation with—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p:
Oh! madam, Robert knows that whole affair—I'll bring him hither directly, and
convict you before the whole company—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Artful, cunning man! you shan't speak to him apart;—you shan't suborn witnesses—I'll pursue you—gentlemen, let me intreat you to step this way—you will be of great service.

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: If we can be of any, madam—

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Faith, I believe all this puzzle has arose from their jealousy; let us see the end of it—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now, Beverley, now Belinda, make good use of your time, and all will be well still.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I see, I see my rashness—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: I have been deceived, I find

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: If she would but forgive my folly—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Why does he not speak to me?—I can't speak first—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Belinda!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Mr. Beverley!— (smiles aside.)

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Don't you think you have been cruel to me, Belinda?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Don't you think you have behaved worse to me, Mr. Beverley?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I have; I grant it; Oh! Belinda!—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: (Without looking at him.) You first disordered my whole frame of mind, and can you wonder—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Oh! my soul, my life, it was all my fault.— (Throws his arm round her waist) do you forgive me?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: (Leaning on his shoulder) You knew the generosity of my temper, the sincerity of my affection, how could you let an extravagance of temper so far get the better—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: I blush for it—do you forgive me?

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: (Drawing closer to him, and smiling)—No—I hate you!—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: (Kissing her cheek) Do you hate me, Belinda?—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Was it not unkind?—Was it not ungenerous?—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: It was—thus on my knees—

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Oh! proud man, have I humbled you once more?—Well, now you are on your knees, I forgive you—Beg my picture back of me this moment—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: (Taking it) Oh! I will adore it ever, and heal this breach with uninterrupted love—

div3.stage: Enter Sir JOHN, Lady RESTLESS, Sir WILLIAM, Mr. BLANDFORD, BELLMONT, and CLARISSA.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—yes, faith, I see we have both made ourselves very ridiculous.—Ha! ha—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: I see and acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Egad! I own it;—I can laugh at my own folly and my wife's too—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Why yes, Sir John, you have been both terribly in the wrong, indeed;—but, Belinda, don't you be in the wrong too—accept of Mr. Beverley this moment.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: If you insist upon it—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: I do insist upon it—

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: Thus let me take the bright reward of all my wishes.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and now it's over; you have but commanded me to gratify my inclinations, for we have both seen our error, and frankly confess we have been in the wrong too.

sp.speaker: Sir WIL.
sp.p: Faith, I think we have been all so; Mr. Blandford, we should not have opposed their inclinations, when we had it in our power to make two such happy matches instead of one—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Very true; and now I wish the young folks all happiness;—and, Sir John, I wish you and your lady happy too—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Sir, it has been a day of mistakes, but of fortunate ones, I hope, and may tend to all our advantage—My lady here will be taught—

sp.speaker: Lady REST.
sp.p: Sir John, I hope you will be taught—

sp.speaker: BLAND.
sp.p: Never mention what is past—the wrangling of married people about any little misconduct is only like the lashing of a top; it serves to keep it up the longer.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: You are very right, Sir; and as we have been all in the wrong this day, we will, for the future, endeavour to be "All in the Right."

div3.stage: Here Lady Restless talks apart with Belinda.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.p: A good proposal, Sir John; we will make it our business, both you who are married, and we who are entering into that state, by mutual confidence, to insure mutual happiness.

sp.speaker: BELIN.
sp.p:
A match, Mr. Beverley; I subscribe to it;—
The god of love thinks we prophane his fire,
When trifles light as air mistrust inspire.
But where esteem and gen'rous passions spring,
There reigns secure, and waves his purple wing;
Gives home-felt peace, prevents the nuptial strife,
Endears the bliss, and bids it last for life.
